commonMistakes.mistake: Displaying user-generated code without XSS protection
commonMistakes.why: Users can inject malicious scripts that execute in viewers' browsers
commonMistakes.impact: Critical security vulnerability - account hijacking, data theft, malware injection
commonMistakes.fix: Always set preventXss: true when code content comes from users or untrusted sources

commonMistakes.mistake: Conflicting canEdit and readOnly settings
commonMistakes.why: canEdit controls UI buttons, options.readOnly controls editor itself - both must align
commonMistakes.impact: Confusing UX - users see edit buttons but cannot edit, or vice versa
commonMistakes.fix: Keep settings consistent: both false for read-only, both true for editable

commonMistakes.mistake: Not validating dynamic content tags before sending
commonMistakes.why: Typos or removed attributes result in broken placeholders in sent content
commonMistakes.impact: Users receive emails with {{user.namee}} or {{removed.field}} instead of actual data
commonMistakes.fix: Enable markNotExistDynamicContent and validate tags before save/send

commonMistakes.mistake: Using fixed pixel sizes for responsive layouts
commonMistakes.why: Editor becomes too small on mobile or too large on desktop
commonMistakes.impact: Poor mobile experience, wasted space on large screens
commonMistakes.fix: Use percentage-based or viewport-relative sizes with usePercentageSize: true
commonMistakes.example:
// WRONG - fixed size breaks on mobile
<InCodeSnippet :size="{ width: '1200px', height: '600px' }" />

// CORRECT - responsive sizing
<InCodeSnippet
  :size="{ width: '100%', height: '60vh' }"
  :usePercentageSize="true"
/>

commonMistakes.mistake: Not handling saveButtonCallback errors
commonMistakes.why: Users think save succeeded when it actually failed
commonMistakes.impact: Data loss - users close editor thinking changes were saved
commonMistakes.fix: Implement proper error handling in save callback with user feedback

valueFormat.notes: The code content to display and edit. Supports HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and other syntax highlighting via CodeMirror. Can include dynamic content placeholders (e.g., {{user.name}}) when canAddDynamicContent is enabled.

commonMistakes.mistake: Not escaping special characters in code content
commonMistakes.why: CodeMirror may interpret certain characters as control sequences
commonMistakes.impact: Code rendering issues or unexpected behavior
commonMistakes.fix: Use proper escaping or enable preventXss for user-generated content

valueFormat.notes: CodeMirror editor configuration. Controls syntax highlighting mode, theme, line numbers, indentation, and other editor features. See CodeMirror documentation for full options.

commonMistakes.mistake: Setting readOnly: true but allowing canEdit: true
commonMistakes.why: Conflicting props create confusing UX
commonMistakes.impact: Users see edit UI but cannot edit code
commonMistakes.fix: Use canEdit: false for read-only mode, or use options.readOnly for CodeMirror-level control

valueFormat.notes: Editor dimensions. Controls width and height of the CodeMirror editor. Use usePercentageSize: true for responsive sizing.
Enables dynamic content (merge tags) insertion. When true, shows UI for inserting placeholders like {{user.name}}, {{product.price}}, etc. Requires dynamicContentBoxProps to configure available tags.
Configuration for dynamic content insertion UI. Defines available merge tags, their labels, and categories. Only effective when canAddDynamicContent is true.
Maps dynamic content placeholders to actual values for preview. Used to show how the code will look with real data instead of {{placeholders}}.
Enables real-time syntax validation. When true, highlights syntax errors and emits checkSyntaxError events. Uses CodeMirror's built-in linting.
List of dynamic content tags that should show warning state. Useful for deprecated or soon-to-expire attributes.
List of dynamic content tags that should show error state. Useful for removed or invalid attributes.
Automatically marks dynamic content tags that don't exist in dynamicContentBoxProps. Helps identify typos or removed attributes.
When true, validates dynamic content tags against fallbackOptions instead of dynamicContentBoxProps. Useful for multi-environment templates.
Regex pattern to whitelist certain dynamic content tags from validation. Useful for allowing custom/user-defined attributes.
Custom callback function for the save button. When provided, overrides default save behavior. Receives the current code as parameter.
Position of action buttons (save/cancel). Controls where the button group appears relative to the editor.
valueFormat.example:
// Buttons at bottom (default)
<InCodeSnippet position="bottom" />

// Buttons at top for long editors
<InCodeSnippet
  :size="{ height: '800px' }"
  position="top"
/>

valueFormat.notes: Alternative configuration for dynamic content when primary source is unavailable. Used as fallback for validation and suggestions.
Enables XSS prevention for user-generated code content. Sanitizes dangerous HTML/JavaScript patterns. CRITICAL for security when displaying user input.
valueFormat.example:
// ALWAYS use for user-generated content
<InCodeSnippet
  :code="userSubmittedCode"
  :preventXss="true"
/>

// Safe to disable for trusted/admin content
<InCodeSnippet
  :code="trustedTemplateCode"
  :preventXss="false"
/>

commonMistakes.mistake: Displaying user-generated code without preventXss: true
commonMistakes.why: Users can inject malicious scripts that execute in other users' browsers
commonMistakes.impact: Critical XSS security vulnerability, data theft, account compromise
commonMistakes.fix: Always set preventXss: true when displaying any user-generated content

input.when: User types, pastes, or modifies code in the editor

checkSyntaxError.description: Emitted when syntax validation detects errors
checkSyntaxError.payload: Array<{ line: number, message: string, severity: string }> - List of syntax errors
checkSyntaxError.when: syntaxCheck is true and syntax errors are detected

markedTags.description: Emitted when dynamic content tags are validated and marked
markedTags.payload: { valid: string[], invalid: string[], warnings: string[] } - Categorized tags
markedTags.when: canAddDynamicContent is true and tags are validated

ready.description: Emitted when CodeMirror editor is initialized and ready

cursorActivity.description: Emitted when cursor position changes in the editor
cursorActivity.payload: { line: number, ch: number } - Cursor position
cursorActivity.when: User moves cursor or selects text

addDynamicAttribute.description: Emitted when user inserts a dynamic content tag
addDynamicAttribute.payload: { name: string, label: string } - The inserted tag
addDynamicAttribute.when: User clicks to insert dynamic content from the picker

updateEventPersistent.description: Emitted when event-related dynamic content is updated
updateEventPersistent.when: Dynamic content related to events is modified

updateProductAttributePersistent.description: Emitted when product attribute dynamic content is updated
updateProductAttributePersistent.when: Dynamic content related to product attributes is modified

helperFunctions.name: useCodeEditor
helperFunctions.description: Composable for managing code editor state with save, reset, and validation functionality
parameters: options: { onSave?: Function, onValidate?: Function, autoSave?: boolean, autoSaveDelay?: number }
helperFunctions.returnType: { code, isDirty, hasErrors, canSave, saving, saveError, syntaxErrors, handleCodeChange, handleSyntaxErrors, save, reset, setCode }

helperFunctions.name: createDynamicContentConfig
helperFunctions.description: Helper to create dynamic content configuration from attribute lists with automatic categorization
parameters: attributes: Attribute[] - List of attributes with name, label, optional category
options: { groupBy?: string, searchable?: boolean, autoCategorizeFn?: Function }
helperFunctions.returnType: { contentObject: Array<{ name, label, category, description }>, groupBy: string, searchable: boolean }

bestPractices.title: Always Enable XSS Protection for User Content
bestPractices.description: Set preventXss: true when displaying any user-generated or untrusted code content
bestPractices.code:
// CRITICAL: Protect against XSS attacks
<InCodeSnippet
  :code="userSubmittedCode"
  :preventXss="true" // Always for user content
/>

// Safe to disable only for trusted/admin content
<InCodeSnippet
  :code="systemTemplate"
  :preventXss="false"
/>
bestPractices.reasoning: Prevents malicious script injection that could compromise user security and data

bestPractices.title: Use Appropriate Editor Size
bestPractices.description: Set editor dimensions based on expected content length and available screen space
bestPractices.reasoning: Optimizes readability and reduces unnecessary scrolling while preventing wasted space

bestPractices.title: Validate Dynamic Content Tags
bestPractices.description: Enable tag validation to catch typos and removed attributes before content is sent
bestPractices.code:
<InCodeSnippet
  :canAddDynamicContent="true"
  :markNotExistDynamicContent="true" // Auto-detect invalid tags
  :warningTags="deprecatedTags" // Mark deprecated tags
  :errorTags="removedTags" // Mark removed tags
  :dynamicContentBoxProps="availableTags"
  @markedTags="handleValidationResults"
/>
bestPractices.reasoning: Prevents sending emails/messages with broken placeholders that display as {{user.unknown}}

bestPractices.title: Configure Syntax Checking for Critical Code
bestPractices.description: Enable syntax validation for configuration files, SQL queries, and production code
bestPractices.code:
<InCodeSnippet
  :syntaxCheck="true"
  :options="{
    mode: 'javascript', // or 'sql', 'python', etc.
    lint: true // Enable linting
  }"
  @checkSyntaxError="preventSaveIfErrors"
/>

const preventSaveIfErrors = (errors: any[]) => {
  if (errors.length > 0) {
    canSave.value = false;
    showErrorMessage('Fix syntax errors before saving');
  }
};
bestPractices.reasoning: Catches errors before they cause runtime failures or break production systems

performanceNotes.description: CodeMirror can slow down with very large files (>5000 lines)
performanceNotes.recommendation: Consider paginating content, using virtual scrolling, or warning users about large files. Disable syntax checking for files over 10,000 lines.
performanceNotes.impact: Significant performance degradation with large files can freeze UI

performanceNotes.description: Validating hundreds of tags on every keystroke impacts performance
performanceNotes.recommendation: Debounce validation by 300-500ms or validate only on blur/save for templates with many tags
performanceNotes.impact: Can cause typing lag in templates with 50+ dynamic content tags

performanceNotes.description: Real-time syntax checking runs on every code change
performanceNotes.recommendation: For complex languages or large files, debounce syntax checking or disable it entirely. Enable only for critical use cases.
performanceNotes.impact: Continuous syntax checking can cause 100-300ms lag on each keystroke for large files

accessibilityNotes.description: CodeMirror provides full keyboard navigation within the editor
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Ensure focus is visible when entering editor. Use focusEditor prop to auto-focus for better keyboard-only navigation.

accessibilityNotes.description: Code editors can be difficult for screen readers to navigate line by line
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Provide alternative text view option or textarea fallback for screen reader users. Consider aria-label describing the editor purpose.

accessibilityNotes.description: Syntax errors should be announced to screen reader users
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Use aria-live region to announce validation errors. Set invalid and invalidMessage props for error state.

accessibilityNotes.description: Syntax highlighting themes may have insufficient contrast
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Choose high-contrast themes or customize colors to meet WCAG AA contrast ratios (4.5:1 for normal text). Test themes with contrast checkers.

basicEditor.title: Basic JavaScript Editor
basicEditor.description: Simple JavaScript code editor with syntax highlighting and line numbers
basicEditor.code:
<template>
  <InCodeSnippet
    v-model:code="jsCode"
    :options="editorOptions"
    :size="{ width: '100%', height: '400px' }"
  />
</template>

<script setup lang="ts">
import { ref } from 'vue';
import { InCodeSnippet } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

const jsCode = ref(`function greet(name) {
  return \`Hello, \${name}!\`;
}

console.log(greet('World'));`);

const editorOptions = {
  mode: 'javascript',
  theme: 'monokai',
  lineNumbers: true,
  tabSize: 2,
  indentUnit: 2
};
</script>

    :code="exampleCode"

      mode: 'javascript',
      theme: 'monokai',
      lineNumbers: true,
      readOnly: true
    }"
    :canEdit="false"
    :size="{ width: '100%', height: '300px' }"
  />
</template>

<script setup lang="ts">
import { ref } from 'vue';
import { InCodeSnippet } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

const exampleCode = ref(`// Example: Array methods
const numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
const doubled = numbers.map(n => n * 2);
console.log(doubled); // [2, 4, 6, 8, 10]`);
</script>

commonMistakes.title: Using V1 'type' prop instead of 'containerType'
commonMistakes.description: InBox V1 used 'type' prop, InContainer V2 uses 'containerType'
commonMistakes.impact: Prop not recognized, defaults to 'default' type

commonMistakes.title: Using CSS values instead of utility classes for border
commonMistakes.description: border prop expects design system utility classes, not CSS values
commonMistakes.impact: Styling not applied, inconsistent with design system

commonMistakes.title: Setting borderTriangle without borderTrianglePosition
commonMistakes.description: Triangle decoration requires position to be specified
commonMistakes.impact: Triangle may not appear or appear in unexpected location

commonMistakes.title: Setting colorIndicatorStatus without colorIndicatorColor
commonMistakes.description: Color indicator needs explicit color value to be visible
commonMistakes.impact: Indicator appears but without color or with default color

commonMistakes.title: Not using contentArea slot
commonMistakes.description: Content should be placed in #contentArea slot for proper structure
commonMistakes.impact: Content may not render correctly or have unexpected styling

commonMistakes.title: Setting headerStatus=true but not using header slots

valueFormat.notes: Shows a decorative triangle pointer on the container border. Must set borderTrianglePosition when true

valueFormat.notes: Position of the border triangle decoration. Only works when borderTriangle is true
Alignment of triangle along its edge (e.g., left/center/right for top position)
Enables the header section with slots for title, description, and action buttons

performanceNotes.description: InContainer is a pure layout component with minimal overhead. No heavy computations or watchers.

performanceNotes.description: Content in slots is only rendered when the slot is used. Unused slots don't add DOM overhead.
performanceNotes.recommendation: Use conditional slots (header, footer) only when needed to minimize DOM size.

accessibilityNotes.description: InContainer provides proper semantic structure with header, main content, and footer sections.

accessibilityNotes.description: Container itself is not interactive, but provides structure for focusable content inside.
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Ensure interactive elements inside container are keyboard accessible.
accessibilityNotes.example: Use proper tab order for form elements inside container.

accessibilityNotes.description: Container background uses design system colors. Verify contrast with content.
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Test text contrast against container background, especially with custom themes.
accessibilityNotes.example: Use design system text colors that meet WCAG AA standards (4.5:1 ratio).

customization.notes: Uses border utility classes from design system for customization. Color indicator uses inline styles.

responsive.notes: Responsive by default. Consider hiding headerLeftSlot or footerLeftSlot on mobile for space

examples.title: Advanced Export Options Menu
examples.description: Feature-rich dropdown with custom templates, search, extra options, and grouped actions

commonMistakes.mistake: Not providing unique values for options
commonMistakes.why: Component relies on value to identify and track selected options
commonMistakes.impact: Selection state breaks, multiple options with same value conflict, cannot distinguish options
commonMistakes.fix: Ensure every option has a unique value property

commonMistakes.mistake: Forgetting to handle @select event
commonMistakes.why: Dropdown emits select event when option is clicked, but nothing happens if not handled
commonMistakes.impact: Users click options but nothing happens, appears broken
commonMistakes.fix: Always implement @select event handler to respond to user selections

commonMistakes.mistake: Using searchStatus for short lists
commonMistakes.why: Search input adds unnecessary UI clutter for few options
commonMistakes.impact: Wasted screen space, slower interaction (must click into search), poor UX
commonMistakes.fix: Only enable search for lists with 10+ options
commonMistakes.example:
// WRONG - search for 3 options
<InCustomDropDown
  :searchStatus="true"
  :options="[
    { label: 'Option 1' },
    { label: 'Option 2' },
    { label: 'Option 3' }
  ]"
/>

// CORRECT
<InCustomDropDown
  :searchStatus="false"
  :options="threeOptions"
/>

commonMistakes.mistake: Not setting avoidClosingSelectors for interactive options
commonMistakes.why: Clicking checkboxes or buttons inside options closes the dropdown
commonMistakes.impact: Frustrating UX - dropdown closes before user finishes interacting
commonMistakes.fix: Use avoidClosingSelectors to specify elements that shouldn't trigger closure

commonMistakes.mistake: Missing error handling in onClick callbacks
commonMistakes.why: Option actions may fail (API errors, validation failures, etc.)
commonMistakes.impact: Silent failures, no user feedback, appears broken
commonMistakes.fix: Wrap async operations in try-catch and provide user feedback

valueFormat.notes: Array of dropdown options. Each option can be a simple object with label/value or include custom template, icons, actions, and metadata. Supports nested options for grouped dropdowns.
valueFormat.typescript:
Array<{
  label: string; // Display text
  value: any; // Option value
  icon?: string; // Optional icon name
  disabled?: boolean; // Disable selection
  active?: boolean; // Initially active/selected
  template?: string; // Custom HTML template
  onClick?: (option) => void; // Click handler
  metadata?: any; // Additional data
  children?: Array<Option>; // Nested options
}>

commonMistakes.mistake: Not providing unique values for each option
commonMistakes.why: Component uses value to track selections and identify options
commonMistakes.impact: Selection state breaks, wrong options get selected, cannot distinguish duplicates
commonMistakes.fix: Ensure every option has a unique value property

valueFormat.notes: Enables search/filter functionality in the dropdown. When true, shows search input at the top of the dropdown menu. Useful for long option lists.
Enables 'Create New' option at the bottom of the dropdown. When clicked, emits event allowing users to add new options dynamically. Useful for tag selection, category creation, etc.
Label text for the 'Create New' option. Only shown when createNewOptionStatus is true.
valueFormat.example:
createNewOptionText="+ Create New Category"
createNewOptionText="+ Add Custom Value"
createNewOptionText="+ Create New Template"

valueFormat.notes: Defines the behavior of dropdown options. 'link' makes options act as links (with href), 'button' makes them act as buttons triggering onClick.
HTML anchor target attribute for link-type options. Controls where links open.
Horizontal alignment of the dropdown menu relative to the trigger button.
Vertical positioning strategy for the dropdown menu. AUTO detects available space and positions accordingly.
Visual style variant for the dropdown trigger button.
Icon name for the dropdown trigger button. Displayed alongside or instead of button text based on iconPosition.
Position of the icon relative to button text.
valueFormat.example:
// Icon on right side (default)
iconPosition="right"
icon="filled-dropdown-down"

// Icon on left side
iconPosition="left"
icon="filter"
text="Filter Options"

valueFormat.notes: Additional option displayed at the top or bottom of the dropdown list with special styling. Typically used for actions like 'Select All', 'Clear Selection', or 'Manage Options'.
CSS selectors for elements that should NOT trigger dropdown closure when clicked. Useful for interactive content within dropdown options like checkboxes, buttons, or nested menus.
Makes the dropdown menu match the full width of its container instead of the trigger button width.
Controls visibility of the trigger button. When false, dropdown can only be triggered programmatically.
Shows border around the dropdown menu.
Disables hover effects on dropdown options. Useful for read-only or display-only dropdowns.
Enables tooltip on the trigger button. Shows tooltipText on hover.
Tooltip content shown when hovering over the trigger button. Only effective when withTooltip is true.
valueFormat.example:
tooltipText="Select export format"
tooltipText="Choose filter criteria"
tooltipText="More actions available"

valueFormat.notes: Dimensions for skeleton loader when skeletonStatus is true.

select.description: Emitted when an option is selected from the dropdown
select.payload: { label: string, value: any, ...optionData } - The selected option object
select.when: User clicks on an option in the dropdown menu

click.description: Emitted when the trigger button is clicked
click.when: User clicks the dropdown trigger button

openList.description: Emitted when the dropdown menu opens

closeList.description: Emitted when the dropdown menu closes

hoverItem.description: Emitted when user hovers over a dropdown option
hoverItem.payload: { label: string, value: any } - The hovered option
hoverItem.when: User moves mouse over an option

clickExtraOption.description: Emitted when the extra option is clicked (when createNewOptionStatus is true or extraOption is set)
clickExtraOption.payload: { label: string, value: any } - The extra option object
clickExtraOption.when: User clicks the create new option or extra option

selectedInActiveOption.description: Emitted when a disabled option is clicked
selectedInActiveOption.payload: { label: string, value: any, disabled: true } - The disabled option
selectedInActiveOption.when: User attempts to click a disabled option

helperFunctions.name: createOptionsFromArray
helperFunctions.description: Helper to transform simple arrays or objects into dropdown option format
parameters: items: T[] - Array of data to transform
config: { labelKey, valueKey, iconKey, disabledKey } - Mapping configuration
helperFunctions.returnType: Array<{ label, value, icon?, disabled? }> - Formatted dropdown options

helperFunctions.name: useDropdownState
helperFunctions.description: Composable for managing dropdown open/close state and selected values
parameters: initialValue: T | null - Initial selected value
helperFunctions.returnType: { isOpen, selectedValue, selectedOption, hoveredOption, open, close, toggle, select, clear, handleHover }

bestPractices.title: Use Search for Long Option Lists
bestPractices.description: Enable searchStatus when dropdown has more than 10-15 options
bestPractices.code:
// GOOD - searchable for many options
<InCustomDropDown
  :options="countriesList" // 200+ countries
  :searchStatus="true"
/>

// BAD - no search for long list
<InCustomDropDown
  :options="countriesList" // 200+ countries - hard to find!
  :searchStatus="false"
/>
bestPractices.reasoning: Users can quickly find options instead of scrolling, improves UX significantly for large lists

bestPractices.title: Provide Clear Action Labels
bestPractices.description: Use descriptive, action-oriented labels for dropdown options
bestPractices.reasoning: Clear labels reduce confusion, prevent errors, and improve accessibility for screen readers

bestPractices.title: Handle Errors in Action Callbacks
bestPractices.description: Implement proper error handling for dropdown option click handlers
bestPractices.reasoning: Prevents silent failures, provides user feedback, improves debugging and reliability

bestPractices.title: Use avoidClosingSelectors for Interactive Content
bestPractices.description: Prevent dropdown from closing when clicking on checkboxes, buttons, or other interactive elements within options
bestPractices.reasoning: Allows users to interact with multi-select checkboxes, buttons, or nested menus without dropdown closing prematurely

performanceNotes.description: Rendering hundreds of options can cause performance issues
performanceNotes.recommendation: For 100+ options, consider virtual scrolling or pagination. Use searchStatus to reduce visible options. Lazy load options if fetching from API.
performanceNotes.impact: 200+ options can cause 500ms+ render delay and slow scrolling

performanceNotes.description: Complex HTML templates for each option increase render time
performanceNotes.recommendation: Keep templates simple. Avoid images or complex CSS in templates. Use CSS classes instead of inline styles. Consider using simple icon + text for most options.
performanceNotes.impact: Complex templates can double render time for large lists

performanceNotes.description: onClick handlers in option objects can create memory leaks if not cleaned up
performanceNotes.recommendation: Use @select event handler instead of individual onClick when possible. If using onClick, ensure proper cleanup in component unmount.
performanceNotes.impact: Memory leaks accumulate over time, especially with dynamic option lists

accessibilityNotes.description: Dropdown must be fully keyboard navigable
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Test with Tab (focus button), Enter/Space (open dropdown), Arrow keys (navigate options), Enter (select), Escape (close). Ensure focus trap within dropdown when open.

accessibilityNotes.description: Dropdown state and options must be announced to screen readers
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Use aria-label on button. Ensure selected option is announced. Use aria-expanded to indicate open/closed state. Provide clear labels for all options.
accessibilityNotes.example:
<InCustomDropDown
  text="Actions"
  aria-label="Available actions for this item"
  :options="options"
/>

accessibilityNotes.description: Focus must return to trigger button after selection or escape
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Component should return focus to button after selection. Test Escape key returns focus properly. Ensure dropdown doesn't trap focus indefinitely.

accessibilityNotes.description: Disabled options must be clearly indicated visually and programmatically
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Use disabled property on options. Ensure disabled options have visual indication (grayed out). Screen readers should announce disabled state.

basicDropdown.title: Basic Action Dropdown
basicDropdown.code:
<template>
  <InCustomDropDown
    id="actions-dropdown"
    text="Actions"
    buttonType="secondary"
    icon="filled-dropdown-down"
    :options="actions"
    @select="handleAction"
  />
</template>

<script setup lang="ts">
import { InCustomDropDown } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

const actions = [
  { label: 'Edit', value: 'edit', icon: 'edit' },
  { label: 'Duplicate', value: 'duplicate', icon: 'copy' },
  { label: 'Archive', value: 'archive', icon: 'archive' },
  { label: 'Delete', value: 'delete', icon: 'delete', disabled: false }
];

const handleAction = (option: any) => {
  console.log('Action selected:', option.value);
  
  switch (option.value) {
    case 'edit':
      editItem();
      break;
    case 'duplicate':
      duplicateItem();
      break;
    case 'archive':
      archiveItem();
      break;
    case 'delete':
      if (confirm('Delete this item?')) {
        deleteItem();
      }
      break;
  }
};

const editItem = () => console.log('Editing...');
const duplicateItem = () => console.log('Duplicating...');
const archiveItem = () => console.log('Archiving...');
const deleteItem = () => console.log('Deleting...');
</script>

examples.title: Server-Side Table with API
examples.description: Table fetching data from API endpoint with authentication
examples.code:
<template>
  <InDataTable
    name="api-table"
    api-mode
    fetch-url="/api/users"
    :table-search-params="searchParams"
    :table-fields="columns"
    :http-options="httpOptions"
    pagination-path="meta.pagination"
    :per-page="25"
    with-search-filter
    with-status-filter
    :status-list="statusOptions"
    @on-load="handleLoad"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
import { ref, computed } from 'vue';

const authToken = ref('Bearer your-token-here');
const tenantId = ref('tenant-123');

const httpOptions = computed(() => ({
  headers: {
    'Authorization': authToken.value,
    'X-Tenant-ID': tenantId.value
  }
}));

const searchParams = computed(() => ({
  tenant: tenantId.value
}));

const columns = ref([
  { field: 'id', label: 'ID', width: 80 },
  { field: 'name', label: 'Name', sortable: true },
  { field: 'email', label: 'Email', sortable: true },
  { field: 'status', label: 'Status' }
]);

const statusOptions = ref([
  { label: 'Active', value: 'active' },
  { label: 'Inactive', value: 'inactive' },
  { label: 'Pending', value: 'pending' }
]);

const handleLoad = (payload) => {
  console.log(`Loaded ${payload.data.length} rows`);
};
</script>

examples.title: Custom HTTP Client with Axios
examples.description: Using custom HTTP client for advanced request handling
examples.code:
<template>
  <InDataTable
    name="axios-table"
    api-mode
    fetch-url="/api/data"
    :http-fetch="axiosClient"
    :table-fields="columns"
    :per-page="20"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
import axios from 'axios';

const axiosClient = async (url, options) => {
  try {
    const response = await axios.get(url, {
      params: options?.params,
      headers: options?.headers,
      timeout: 10000 // 10 second timeout
    });
    
    // Convert axios response to fetch Response
    return new Response(JSON.stringify(response.data), {
      status: response.status,
      statusText: response.statusText,
      headers: new Headers(response.headers)
    });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('API Error:', error);
    throw error;
  }
};

const columns = ref([
  { field: 'id', label: 'ID' },
  { field: 'name', label: 'Name', sortable: true }
]);
</script>

import { ref } from 'vue';

const items = ref([

]);

const rowActions = ref([
  {
    name: 'edit',
    icon: 'line-edit',
    label: 'Edit',
    handler: (row) => {
      console.log('Edit:', row.id);

    }
  },
  {
    name: 'delete',
    icon: 'line-trash',
    label: 'Delete',
    handler: async (row) => {
      if (confirm(`Delete ${row.name}?`)) {
        // await deleteItem(row.id);
        console.log('Deleted:', row.id);
      }
    }
  }
]);
</script>

examples.title: Formatted Values
examples.description: Custom formatting for dates, currency, and status
examples.code:
<template>
  <InDataTable
    name="formatted-table"
    :data="transactions"
    :table-fields="columns"
    :format-mapping="formatters"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
import { ref } from 'vue';

const transactions = ref([
  { id: 1, amount: 1234.56, createdAt: '2025-01-15T10:30:00Z', status: 'completed' }
]);

const columns = ref([
  { field: 'id', label: 'ID' },
  { field: 'amount', label: 'Amount' },
  { field: 'createdAt', label: 'Date' },
  { field: 'status', label: 'Status' }
]);

const formatters = ref({
  amount: (value) => `$${parseFloat(value).toFixed(2)}`,
  createdAt: (value) => new Date(value).toLocaleDateString('en-US', {
    year: 'numeric',
    month: 'short',
    day: 'numeric'
  }),
  status: (value) => value.charAt(0).toUpperCase() + value.slice(1)
});
</script>

examples.title: Conditional Row Styling
examples.description: Dynamic row classes based on row data
examples.code:
<template>
  <InDataTable
    name="styled-table"
    :data="items"
    :table-fields="columns"
    :row-class="getRowClass"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
import { ref } from 'vue';

const items = ref([
  { id: 1, name: 'Item 1', status: 'error', priority: 'high' },
  { id: 2, name: 'Item 2', status: 'success', priority: 'low' }
]);

const columns = ref([
  { field: 'name', label: 'Name' },
  { field: 'status', label: 'Status' },
  { field: 'priority', label: 'Priority' }
]);

const getRowClass = (row) => {
  if (row.status === 'error') return 'bg-red-50 text-red-900';
  if (row.status === 'success') return 'bg-green-50';
  if (row.priority === 'high') return 'font-bold';
  return '';
};
</script>

<style scoped>
.bg-red-50 { background-color: #ffebee; }
.text-red-900 { color: #b71c1c; }
.bg-green-50 { background-color: #e8f5e9; }
</style>

examples.title: Loading States
examples.description: Skeleton loading for better UX
examples.code:
<template>
  <InDataTable
    name="loading-table"
    api-mode
    fetch-url="/api/data"
    :table-fields="columns"
    :loading-status="isLoading"
    loading-type="skeleton"
    @on-load="handleLoad"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
import { ref } from 'vue';

const isLoading = ref(false);

const columns = ref([
  { field: 'id', label: 'ID' },
  { field: 'name', label: 'Name' }
]);

const handleLoad = () => {
  isLoading.value = false;
};
</script>

commonMistakes.title: Using fetchUrl without apiMode=true
commonMistakes.description: Table needs apiMode enabled to fetch from URL
commonMistakes.impact: Table shows empty state, no data fetched

commonMistakes.title: Missing 'field' property in tableFields
commonMistakes.description: Each column definition must have 'field' matching data key
commonMistakes.impact: Columns show undefined values or don't render

commonMistakes.title: httpFetch not returning Promise<Response>
commonMistakes.description: Custom HTTP client must return proper Response object
commonMistakes.correct: :http-fetch="async (url, opts) => { const res = await axios.get(url); return new Response(JSON.stringify(res.data), { status: res.status }); }"
commonMistakes.impact: Table loading fails with type errors

commonMistakes.title: Missing Authorization header for protected APIs
commonMistakes.description: Authenticated endpoints require auth headers in httpOptions
commonMistakes.impact: API requests fail with 401 Unauthorized

commonMistakes.title: Wrong paginationPath for API response
commonMistakes.description: Path must match your API's pagination data location
commonMistakes.wrong: pagination-path="pagination" for API response { meta: { pagination: {...} } }
commonMistakes.impact: Pagination broken, wrong page counts

commonMistakes.title: Using 'title' instead of 'label' in tableFields
commonMistakes.description: V1 uses 'label' property for column headers
commonMistakes.impact: Column headers don't display

commonMistakes.title: Loading large datasets client-side
commonMistakes.description: Client-side mode not suitable for > 1000 rows
commonMistakes.impact: Page freezes, poor performance

commonMistakes.title: Complex logic in rowClass function
commonMistakes.description: rowClass called for every row on every render
commonMistakes.impact: Table re-renders slowly, performance issues

valueFormat.notes: REQUIRED: Array of column definition objects. Each must have 'field' and 'label' properties
examples: [{ field: 'id', label: 'ID', width: 80 }, { field: 'email', label: 'Email', sortable: true, renderer: 'email' }]
valueFormat.typescript: Array<{ field: string; label: string; sortable?: boolean; width?: number; renderer?: string; formatter?: Function; }>

commonMistakes.mistake: Not providing 'field' property in column definition
commonMistakes.impact: Column shows undefined or doesn't render
commonMistakes.fix: Each column must have: { field: 'propertyName', label: 'Display Name' }

commonMistakes.mistake: Using 'title' instead of 'label' for column header
commonMistakes.impact: Column header doesn't display
commonMistakes.fix: V1 uses 'label' property, not 'title'

commonMistakes.mistake: Field name doesn't match data object keys
commonMistakes.impact: Column shows empty values
commonMistakes.fix: Ensure field: 'email' matches data object key: { email: 'test@example.com' }

valueFormat.notes: CRITICAL: Custom HTTP client function for API requests. Use when you need custom auth, interceptors, or error handling. Replaces default fetch behavior

commonMistakes.mistake: Not returning a Promise from httpFetch
commonMistakes.impact: Table loading fails silently or throws errors
commonMistakes.fix: httpFetch must return Promise<Response>: async (url, options) => await fetch(url, options)

commonMistakes.mistake: Using httpFetch without setting apiMode=true
commonMistakes.impact: Custom fetch function never gets called
commonMistakes.fix: Always set api-mode when providing :http-fetch

commonMistakes.mistake: Not handling errors in custom httpFetch
commonMistakes.impact: Unhandled promise rejections, poor error UX
commonMistakes.fix: Wrap in try-catch and return proper Response: try { return await axios(...) } catch (e) { throw new Error(...) }

commonMistakes.mistake: Forgetting to merge httpOptions into custom fetch
commonMistakes.impact: Headers and credentials from httpOptions prop are ignored
commonMistakes.fix: Merge options: httpFetch: (url, opts) => fetch(url, { ...opts, ...httpOptions.value })

valueFormat.notes: Table data array for client-side mode (when apiMode=false). Each object represents a row

commonMistakes.mistake: Providing both :data and fetch-url
commonMistakes.impact: Confusing behavior - which data source is used depends on apiMode
commonMistakes.fix: Use :data for client-side OR fetch-url for server-side, not both

valueFormat.notes: API endpoint for server-side data fetching. Requires apiMode=true

commonMistakes.mistake: Using fetchUrl without setting apiMode=true
commonMistakes.impact: Table doesn't fetch data, shows empty state
commonMistakes.fix: Always set api-mode when using fetch-url

commonMistakes.mistake: Not handling CORS for external APIs
commonMistakes.impact: API requests fail with CORS errors
commonMistakes.fix: Ensure API has proper CORS headers or use proxy

valueFormat.notes: Enable server-side data fetching. When true, uses fetchUrl instead of local data
Additional query parameters sent with API requests. Merged with pagination/sort/filter params
Row action buttons configuration. Creates action column with buttons for each row
valueFormat.typescript: Array<{ name: string; icon?: string; label?: string; handler?: (row: any) => void; }>

valueFormat.notes: Number of rows per page. Default: 10
Default sort configuration applied on initial load
JSON path to pagination data in API response. Uses dot notation for nested objects

commonMistakes.mistake: Wrong pagination path for API response structure
commonMistakes.impact: Pagination doesn't work, shows wrong page count
commonMistakes.fix: Inspect API response and set correct path: pagination-path="meta.pagination"

valueFormat.notes: HTTP request configuration for API calls (headers, credentials, etc.)

commonMistakes.mistake: Not providing Authorization header for authenticated APIs
commonMistakes.impact: API requests fail with 401 Unauthorized
commonMistakes.fix: Pass auth header: :http-options="{ headers: { 'Authorization': `Bearer ${token}` } }"

valueFormat.notes: Unique identifier field for row tracking. Critical for selection and detail rows. Default: 'id'

commonMistakes.mistake: Using non-unique field for trackBy
commonMistakes.impact: Row selection breaks, detail rows don't work properly
commonMistakes.fix: Use truly unique field: track-by="id" or track-by="uuid"

valueFormat.notes: Custom formatter functions for specific fields. Maps field names to formatter functions
Dynamic class applied to rows based on row data. Can be string or function

commonMistakes.mistake: Complex logic in rowClass function
commonMistakes.impact: Performance issues - function called for every row on every render
commonMistakes.fix: Keep function simple or memoize results

valueFormat.notes: Type of loading indicator shown during data fetch

payloadFormat.notes: Emitted when table data is loaded (both initial and refreshes)

payloadFormat.structure: { page: number, perPage: number, total: number }
payloadFormat.notes: Emitted when pagination state changes (page change, perPage change)
Emitted with total record count from API response
Emitted when user changes per-page selection in pagination dropdown
Emitted when row selection changes. selectedRows contains full row objects

helperFunctions.name: createTableField
helperFunctions.description: Create table field definition with common settings
helperFunctions.example: const nameField = createTableField('name', 'User Name', { sortable: true, width: '200px' });

helperFunctions.name: createSortableFields
helperFunctions.description: Make multiple fields sortable at once
helperFunctions.example: const fields = createSortableFields([{ field: 'name', label: 'Name' }, { field: 'date', label: 'Date' }]);

helperFunctions.name: filterTableData
helperFunctions.description: Filter table data by search term across multiple fields
helperFunctions.example: const filtered = filterTableData(users, 'john', ['name', 'email', 'department']);

helperFunctions.name: sortTableData
helperFunctions.description: Sort table data by field and direction
helperFunctions.example: const sorted = sortTableData(users, 'name', 'asc');

helperFunctions.name: paginateData
helperFunctions.description: Get paginated slice of data array
helperFunctions.returnType: { data: Array<any>, total: number, page: number, perPage: number, totalPages: number }
helperFunctions.example: const paginated = paginateData(users, 2, 25); // Page 2, 25 items per page

bestPractices.practice: Always set trackBy for tables with selection or detail rows
bestPractices.why: Ensures proper row identification and prevents selection bugs
bestPractices.antiPattern: Omitting trackBy with non-unique default 'id' field

bestPractices.why: Client-side rendering of large datasets causes performance issues
bestPractices.example: api-mode fetch-url="/api/users" for large user lists

bestPractices.practice: Provide httpOptions for all authenticated API calls
bestPractices.why: Without auth headers, API requests will fail
bestPractices.antiPattern: Expecting table to inherit global axios interceptors

bestPractices.practice: Use formatMapping for consistent value formatting
bestPractices.why: Centralizes formatting logic, easier to maintain
bestPractices.antiPattern: Custom renderer components for simple formatting

bestPractices.practice: Set proper paginationPath for your API response structure
bestPractices.why: Incorrect path causes pagination to break
bestPractices.antiPattern: Guessing pagination path without inspecting API response

bestPractices.why: Complex functions hurt performance (called for every row on every render)

bestPractices.practice: Use loading states for better UX
bestPractices.why: Users need feedback during data fetches
bestPractices.antiPattern: No loading indicator, users see empty table during fetch

performanceNotes.description: Client-side mode loads all data into memory. API mode fetches paginated data from server.
performanceNotes.recommendation: Use client-side for < 1000 rows. Use API mode (fetch-url) for larger datasets to avoid memory issues and slow initial load.

performanceNotes.description: Custom renderers (rowClass, cellRenderer) are called on every render for every visible row.
performanceNotes.recommendation: Keep renderer functions simple. Avoid expensive calculations, API calls, or complex logic. Cache computed values outside the function.

performanceNotes.description: Table watches data prop for changes. Deep watching large arrays is expensive.
performanceNotes.recommendation: When updating data, replace the entire array instead of mutating (data.value = [...newData]) to trigger efficient re-renders.

accessibilityNotes.description: InDataTable renders semantic HTML table with proper thead, tbody structure.
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Ensure table headers (tableFields.label) are descriptive for screen readers.
accessibilityNotes.example: { field: 'email', label: 'User Email Address' } // Descriptive label

accessibilityNotes.description: Sortable column headers are keyboard accessible with Enter/Space keys.
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: No action needed - component handles keyboard interaction internally.

accessibilityNotes.description: Selected rows should be announced to screen readers.
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Use aria-label on action buttons that operate on selected rows to provide context.

accessibilityNotes.description: When table has no data, empty state should be announced.
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Provide meaningful empty-text message that explains why table is empty.
accessibilityNotes.example: empty-text="No users found matching your filters" // Context for screen readers

customization.notes: Use rowClass prop for dynamic row styling. Fixed columns use position: sticky

responsive.notes: Use horizontal-scroll on mobile for wide tables. Consider hiding less important columns on mobile

implementationPatterns.when: Fetching data from authenticated API endpoints
implementationPatterns.notes: Use computed for httpOptions to react to auth token changes

implementationPatterns.when: Need resilient API calls with automatic retries
implementationPatterns.notes: Exponential backoff: 1s, 2s, 3s delays between retries

implementationPatterns.when: Table needs to auto-refresh with latest data

implementationPatterns.when: Users need to export selected table data
implementationPatterns.notes: Store selected rows from selectStatus event

InDataTableV2.name: InDataTableV2
InDataTableV2.title: In Data Table

metadata.description: Complex data table with sorting, pagination, and filtering

commonMistakes.mistake: Using tableFields instead of columnOptions
commonMistakes.issue: V1 prop name won't work in V2
commonMistakes.solution: Rename tableFields to columnOptions and update column structure

commonMistakes.mistake: Using 'label' instead of 'headerName' in columns
commonMistakes.solution: V2 uses AG Grid format: use headerName instead of label

commonMistakes.mistake: Using api-mode boolean instead of row-model-type
Using perPage instead of defaultItemPerPage
commonMistakes.issue: Items per page not set correctly

commonMistakes.mistake: Using withSearchFilter instead of searchFilterStatus
Expecting @onLoad event
Not handling AG Grid column definition format
commonMistakes.issue: Advanced features like filters don't work
commonMistakes.solution: V2 uses AG Grid format - add filter: true, sortable: true explicitly

columnOptions.description: Column definitions array - replaces V1 tableFields

valueFormat.structure: Array of AG Grid column definitions
valueFormat.notes: CRITICAL: Defines table structure using AG Grid format (not V1 format!). Each column needs 'field' (data property) and 'headerName' (column title). Optional: sortable, filter, width, pinned ('left'/'right'), cellRenderer for custom rendering. V2 is built on AG Grid - use AG Grid column definition format with all its features (valueFormatter, cellClass, cellStyle, etc.).
valueFormat.typescript: Array<{ field: string; headerName: string; sortable?: boolean; filter?: boolean; width?: number; pinned?: 'left' | 'right'; cellRenderer?: string; valueFormatter?: Function; }>
valueFormat.example: :column-options="[{ field: 'name', headerName: 'Name', sortable: true, filter: true }, { field: 'email', headerName: 'Email', width: 200 }]"

commonMistakes.mistake: Using 'label' instead of 'headerName' from V1
commonMistakes.impact: Column headers display as undefined or blank
commonMistakes.fix: Change all 'label' to 'headerName' in column definitions

commonMistakes.mistake: Using V1 renderer names
commonMistakes.impact: Custom cell renderers don't work, cells show raw data
commonMistakes.fix: Use AG Grid cellRenderer format with component name strings

data.description: Table data array for client-side mode

valueFormat.notes: Array of data objects to display in the table. Each object represents one row, with properties matching column 'field' values. Only used in clientSide rowModelType. For serverSide mode, data is fetched from API via fetchUrl. Update this array to refresh table content (reactive).

totalData.description: Total number of records (for server-side pagination display)

valueFormat.notes: Total record count for server-side pagination. Used to calculate total pages and show 'X of Y' items. Only relevant in serverSide rowModelType - in clientSide mode, total is auto-calculated from data array length. Backend should return this in API response.

rowModelType.description: Data loading mode - replaces V1 apiMode

valueFormat.notes: Determines how table loads data. 'clientSide' (default) loads all data upfront into browser - use for <1000 rows. 'serverSide' fetches data paginated from API via fetchUrl - use for large datasets (10K+ rows). 'infinite' enables infinite scroll. CRITICAL V1 CHANGE: V1 used boolean api-mode, V2 uses string row-model-type.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using api-mode boolean from V1
commonMistakes.impact: Prop not recognized, table doesn't fetch from API
commonMistakes.fix: Change :api-mode="true" to row-model-type="serverSide"

fetchUrl.description: API endpoint URL for server-side data fetching

valueFormat.notes: API endpoint URL for fetching table data in serverSide mode. Table will POST/GET (based on httpMethod) to this URL with pagination/filter/sort params. Requires rowModelType="serverSide". Backend should return data array and totalData count. Use tableSearchParams for additional custom params.

HTTP method used when fetching data from fetchUrl. GET sends params in query string, POST sends in request body. Use POST for complex filters or when URL length might exceed limits. Only relevant in serverSide rowModelType.

bulkActionsOptions.description: Bulk action buttons for selected rows

valueFormat.notes: Defines bulk action buttons shown when rows are selected. Each action needs id (unique identifier), label (button text). Optional: icon, variant ('danger' for destructive actions), disabled. Actions trigger @bulk-action event with actionId and selectedRows. Use for operations like export, delete, archive on multiple rows.
valueFormat.typescript: Array<{ id: string; label: string; icon?: string; variant?: string; disabled?: boolean; }>

valueFormat.notes: Shows bulk actions toolbar when rows are selected. Requires rowsSelection to be enabled and bulkActionsOptions to be provided. When true, toolbar appears above table showing action buttons and selected count. Essential for multi-row operations.

'multiple' allows selecting many rows with checkboxes, 'single' allows only one row selected at a time. Checkboxes appear in first column. Use with @select-status/@row-selected events to track selections. Essential for bulk operations or row-based actions.

canSelectAllRows.description: Enable select all checkbox in header

valueFormat.notes: Shows 'select all' checkbox in table header for selecting all rows at once. Only works with rowsSelection="multiple". When clicked, selects all visible rows (respects pagination). Use for bulk operations where users might want to select entire page.

rowHeight.description: Height of each row in pixels

valueFormat.notes: Row height preset or custom pixel value. 'small' (48px) for compact tables, 'medium' (64px) default for comfortable viewing, or custom number for specific height. Fixed row height improves scroll performance in large tables. AG Grid uses this for virtualization calculations.

Wraps entire table in InContainer component for consistent styling with headers, borders, shadows. Use inContainerLayoutOptions to configure container appearance (title, borders, etc.). Essential for matching Design System container patterns across application.

Configuration for InContainer wrapper when inContainerLayout=true. headerStatus adds header section, title sets header text, border adds container borders. Passes props directly to InContainer component. Use for consistent table presentation.
valueFormat.typescript: { headerStatus?: boolean; title?: string; border?: boolean; }

valueFormat.notes: Enables master-detail pattern with expandable rows showing nested tables. When row is expanded, shows child table with data from nestedTableFields columns. Perfect for orders→order items, users→permissions, invoices→line items. Emit @nested-data-ready to load nested data.

valueFormat.structure: Array of column definitions (same as columnOptions)
valueFormat.notes: Column definitions for the nested/child table shown when row expands. Same format as columnOptions - AG Grid column definitions. Used with nestedTableStatus. Define columns for child data structure (e.g., order items have product, quantity, price columns).
valueFormat.typescript: Array<{ field: string; headerName: string; width?: number; }>

valueFormat.notes: Displays hierarchical/tree data with expand/collapse functionality. Rows can have child rows creating tree structure (org charts, file systems, category hierarchies). Use groupDataPath to define how to access child nodes. Rows show expand/collapse icons automatically.

groupDataPath.description: Path to child nodes in tree data

valueFormat.notes: Function that returns path to child nodes in tree data structure. Used with isTreeData. Function receives row data and should return array of property names leading to children. Example: for org hierarchy stored in row.children, return ['children']. For nested like row.org.children, return ['org', 'children'].

searchFilterStatus.description: Show search input - replaces V1 withSearchFilter

valueFormat.notes: Shows global search input above table for filtering rows. Searches across all columns (client-side) or sends search param to API (server-side). V1 CHANGE: V1 used withSearchFilter, V2 uses searchFilterStatus. Emits @set-search-value event with search query.

Placeholder text shown in search input when empty. Use descriptive text like 'Search users...', 'Find orders...'. Helps users understand what they can search for. Only relevant when searchFilterStatus=true.

statusFilterStatus.description: Show status filter dropdown - replaces V1 withStatusFilter

valueFormat.notes: Shows status filter dropdown above table for filtering by predefined statuses. Options come from statusFilterList. Common for filtering by Active/Inactive, Published/Draft, etc. V1 CHANGE: V1 used withStatusFilter, V2 uses statusFilterStatus.

statusFilterList.description: Options for status filter - replaces V1 statusList

valueFormat.notes: Status options for the filter dropdown. Each option needs label (display text) and value (filter value sent to API). Used with statusFilterStatus. V1 CHANGE: V1 used statusList, V2 uses statusFilterList. Common values: Active/Inactive, All statuses, Published/Draft.
valueFormat.typescript: Array<{ label: string; value: string | number; }>

valueFormat.notes: Shows pagination controls below table (page numbers, prev/next buttons). Essential for large datasets. Works in both clientSide (splits data array) and serverSide (fetches pages from API) modes. Emits @pagination-changed when page changes.

Shows dropdown to change items per page (10, 25, 50, 100). Options range from minItemPerPage to maxItemPerPage. Allows users to control page size. Emits @per-page-selected when changed. Use with paginationStatus.

defaultItemPerPage.description: Default number of items per page - replaces V1 perPage

valueFormat.notes: Initial/default page size when table loads. V1 CHANGE: V1 used perPage, V2 uses defaultItemPerPage. Common values: 10 (default), 25, 50, 100. Choose based on data density and user needs. Smaller for detailed rows, larger for simple data.
Minimum page size option in items-per-page dropdown. Usually 10 or 25. Prevents users from selecting too small page sizes that require excessive clicking. Used to generate dropdown options.
Maximum page size option in items-per-page dropdown. Usually 100 or 200. Prevents performance issues from rendering too many rows at once. Used to generate dropdown options (min, default, max, etc.).

showingItemsStatus.description: Show 'Showing X of Y items' text

valueFormat.notes: Shows text like 'Showing 1-25 of 1,523 items' below table. Helps users understand current view and total data size. Especially useful in serverSide mode to show total from backend. Part of pagination information section.

Shows entire pagination info section (page count text, page size selector). Master toggle for pagination UI elements. When false, hides all pagination info except page number buttons. Use to simplify UI for small datasets.

Triggers loading state overlay on table. Shows spinner or skeleton based on loadingType. Use while fetching data (initial load or refresh). Prevents user interaction during load. Emits @loading-status event when changed.

Shows skeleton placeholder rows instead of spinner during loading. Better UX for initial load - users see table structure. Number of skeleton columns from horizontalSkeletonsCount. Use for first load, loadingStatus for refreshes.
valueFormat.example: skeleton-status // Show skeleton during initial load

horizontalSkeletonsCount.description: Number of skeleton columns to show

valueFormat.notes: Number of skeleton columns to render during skeleton loading. Should match actual column count for best visual effect. Default is 6. Used only when skeletonStatus=true or loadingType='skeleton'.

'skeleton' shows placeholder rows (better for initial load), 'spinner' shows loading spinner (better for refreshes). Determines loading UI when loadingStatus=true. Skeleton provides better perceived performance.

Title text shown in loading overlay. Appears above spinner/skeleton. Use descriptive text like 'Loading data...', 'Fetching users...'. Provides context during wait. Only shows when loadingStatus=true.
Subtitle/description text in loading overlay. Appears below title. Use for additional context like 'Please wait', 'This may take a moment'. Optional, can be empty for minimal UI.

noDataTitleText.description: Title when no data - replaces V1 noDataTitle

valueFormat.notes: Title text shown in empty state when table has no data. V1 CHANGE: V1 used noDataTitle, V2 uses noDataTitleText. Use clear messages like 'No results found', 'No users yet'. Helps users understand empty table.
valueFormat.example: no-data-title-text="No results found" // Empty state title

noDataDescriptionText.description: Description when no data - replaces V1 noDataDescription

valueFormat.notes: Description text shown below title in empty state. V1 CHANGE: V1 used noDataDescription, V2 uses noDataDescriptionText. Provide helpful guidance like 'Try adjusting filters', 'Click + to add first item'. Actionable suggestions improve UX.
valueFormat.example: no-data-description-text="Try adjusting your filters" // Empty state hint

valueFormat.notes: Customization options for empty state. icon sets empty state icon, buttonText shows action button, buttonAction defines click handler. Use to add 'Clear Filters', 'Add First Item' buttons in empty state. Makes empty state actionable.
valueFormat.typescript: { icon?: string; buttonText?: string; buttonAction?: Function; }

autoHeight.description: Auto-adjust table height based on content

valueFormat.notes: Table height automatically fits content (no vertical scroll). Grows/shrinks with row count. Use for small, variable datasets. DON'T use with large datasets - causes performance issues. Conflicts with fixedHeight. AG Grid disables virtualization with autoHeight.

Sets fixed table height in pixels. Table scrolls vertically when content exceeds height. Use for large datasets to maintain consistent UI. Enables AG Grid virtualization for performance. Conflicts with autoHeight. Common values: 400, 500, 600px.

Enables horizontal scrolling when columns exceed table width. Essential for tables with many columns. Use with pinned columns to keep important columns visible while scrolling. AG Grid handles scroll virtualization automatically.

Limits how many columns can be pinned (fixed left/right). Prevents users from pinning too many columns which hurts UX. When limit reached, emits @max-columns-pinned event. Common limit: 2-3 columns. Use to balance flexibility with usability.

Enables Excel-like cell range selection with mouse drag or Shift+Click. Users can select rectangular cell ranges. Useful for copy-paste operations or bulk cell editing. AG Grid provides built-in range selection UI and keyboard shortcuts.

Allows selecting and copying text inside cells. When false, prevents text selection (better for row selection UX). When true, users can select cell content for copying. Trade-off: easier copy vs cleaner row selection interaction.

rowDragManaged.description: Enable row drag and drop reordering

valueFormat.notes: Enables dragging rows to reorder them. Shows drag handle in first column. Emits @row-drag-end/@row-drag-stopped events with new order. Perfect for priority lists, task ordering, manual sorting. Use @row-drag-stopped to persist new order to backend.

customColumnMenuItems.description: Custom items for column context menu

valueFormat.notes: Adds custom items to column header context menu (right-click menu). Each item needs name (label) and action (click handler). Optional icon. Use for column-specific operations like 'Export Column', 'Hide Column', 'Pin Column'. Extends default AG Grid menu.
valueFormat.typescript: Array<{ name: string; action: Function; icon?: string; }>

valueFormat.notes: Enables mobile-optimized responsive behavior. Table adapts layout for small screens - columns may stack, simplified interactions. Use for mobile-first or responsive applications. May hide some columns on small screens automatically.

tableSearchParams.description: Additional parameters to send with search/filter requests in server-side mode

valueFormat.notes: Only used in serverSide row model. Merged with pagination/filter params in API requests

commonMistakes.mistake: Using tableSearchParams in clientSide mode
commonMistakes.impact: Params are ignored, not sent to API (no API calls in clientSide)
commonMistakes.fix: Only use with row-model-type="serverSide" for API fetching

commonMistakes.mistake: Not reactively updating tableSearchParams
commonMistakes.impact: Param changes don't trigger table refresh
commonMistakes.fix: Use ref/reactive: const params = ref({ status: 'active' })

dataLoaded.description: Emitted when table data is loaded

dataReady.description: Emitted when grid is ready with data

firstDataRendered.description: Emitted when first data is rendered

rowSelected.payload: { node: RowNode, data: any, selected: boolean }

allRowsSelected.description: Emitted when all rows are selected

bulkAction.description: Emitted when bulk action is triggered

cellClicked.payload: { colId: string, data: any, value: any }

maxColumnsPinned.description: Emitted when max pinned columns reached

copied.description: Emitted when data is copied to clipboard

nestedDataReady.description: Emitted when nested table data is ready

rowGroupStatusChanged.description: Emitted when row group expand/collapse changes

loadingStatus.notes: Emitted when table starts/stops loading data. Useful for showing global loading indicators

rowDragEnter.description: Emitted when dragged row enters a drop zone
rowDragEnter.payload: { node: RowNode, overNode: RowNode, event: DragEvent }
rowDragEnter.notes: Fires when dragging row over another row. Use with row-drag-managed prop

rowDragMove.payload: { node: RowNode, overNode: RowNode, event: DragEvent }
rowDragMove.notes: Fires continuously while dragging. Use for visual feedback during drag

rowDragLeave.description: Emitted when dragged row leaves a drop zone
rowDragLeave.payload: { node: RowNode, overNode: RowNode, event: DragEvent }
rowDragLeave.notes: Fires when drag exits a row area. Use to clear hover states

rowDragCancel.description: Emitted when row drag operation is cancelled
rowDragCancel.notes: Fires when user cancels drag (ESC key or invalid drop). Use to reset UI state

rowDragStopped.description: Emitted when row drag operation stops (successful or not)
rowDragStopped.notes: Always fires at end of drag operation. Use for cleanup regardless of success/failure

examples.title: Basic V1 Date Range Picker
examples.description: Simple date range picker without custom ranges
examples.code:
<template>
  <InDatePicker
    id="date-picker"
    label="Select Period"
    :value="dateValue"
    :min-date="minDate"
    :max-date="maxDate"
    :locale="locale"
    :format-mapping="formatMapping"
    :additional-ranges="true"
    open-position="right"
    @update="handleUpdate" />
</template>

<script>
import { InDatePicker } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

export default {
  components: { InDatePicker },
  
  data() {
    return {
      startDate: '01/12/2024',
      endDate: '20/12/2024',
      minDate: '01/01/2023',
      maxDate: new Date().toLocaleDateString('en-US'),
      locale: 'en-US',
      formatMapping: {
        'en-US': 'mm/dd/yyyy',
        'tr-TR': 'dd.mm.yyyy',
        'default': 'mm/dd/yyyy'
      }
    };
  },
  
  computed: {
    dateValue() {
      // V1: Plain object (NOT array)
      return {
        startDate: this.startDate,
        endDate: this.endDate
      };
    }
  },
  
  methods: {
    handleUpdate(rangeStr) {
      // V1 always returns string: "mm/dd/yyyy-mm/dd/yyyy"
      const [start, end] = rangeStr.split('-');
      this.startDate = start;
      this.endDate = end;
      
      console.log('Date range selected:', { start, end });
    }
  }
};
</script>

examples.title: With Custom Ranges & Disabled Dates
examples.description: V1 date picker with custom quick ranges and disabled date range
examples.code:
<template>
  <InDatePicker
    id="date-picker-custom"
    label="Reporting Period"
    :value="dateValue"
    :custom-date-range="true"
    :custom-ranges="customRanges"
    :disabled-range="disabledRange"
    :additional-ranges="true"
    :locale="locale"
    :format-mapping="formatMapping"
    open-position="center"
    @update="handleUpdate" />
</template>

<script>
import { InDatePicker } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

export default {
  components: { InDatePicker },
  
  data() {
    return {
      startDate: '10/01/2024',
      endDate: '12/31/2024',
      locale: 'en-US',
      formatMapping: {
        'en-US': 'mm/dd/yyyy',
        'default': 'mm/dd/yyyy'
      },
      // V1 custom ranges: Object with Date arrays
      customRanges: {
        'Q4 2024': [new Date('2024-10-01'), new Date('2024-12-31')],
        'Q3 2024': [new Date('2024-07-01'), new Date('2024-09-30')],
        'H2 2024': [new Date('2024-07-01'), new Date('2024-12-31')],
        'Full Year': [new Date('2024-01-01'), new Date('2024-12-31')]
      },
      // V1 disabled range: Unix timestamps in SECONDS
      disabledRange: [
        Math.floor(new Date('2024-12-25').getTime() / 1000), // Christmas
        Math.floor(new Date('2024-12-26').getTime() / 1000)
      ]
    };
  },
  
  computed: {
    dateValue() {
      return {
        startDate: this.startDate,
        endDate: this.endDate
      };
    }
  },
  
  methods: {
    handleUpdate(rangeStr) {
      const [start, end] = rangeStr.split('-');
      this.startDate = start;
      this.endDate = end;
      
      // Update analytics or fetch data
      this.fetchReportData(start, end);
    },
    
    fetchReportData(startDate, endDate) {
      console.log('Fetching data for:', startDate, 'to', endDate);
      // API call here
    }
  }
};
</script>

examples.title: Turkish Locale with Dot Format
examples.description: V1 date picker configured for Turkish locale with dd.mm.yyyy format
examples.code:
<template>
  <InDatePicker
    id="date-picker-tr"
    label="Tarih Aralığı Seçin"
    :value="dateValue"
    :locale="'tr-TR'"
    :format-mapping="formatMapping"
    :additional-ranges="true"
    :custom-date-range="true"
    :custom-ranges="customRanges"
    separator=" - "
    @update="handleUpdate" />
</template>

<script>
import { InDatePicker } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

export default {
  components: { InDatePicker },
  
  data() {
    return {
      startDate: '01.12.2024',
      endDate: '31.12.2024',
      formatMapping: {
        'tr-TR': 'dd.mm.yyyy',
        'default': 'dd.mm.yyyy'
      },
      customRanges: {
        'Son Çeyrek': [new Date('2024-10-01'), new Date('2024-12-31')],
        'Bu Yıl': [new Date('2024-01-01'), new Date('2024-12-31')]
      }
    };
  },
  
  computed: {
    dateValue() {
      return {
        startDate: this.startDate,
        endDate: this.endDate
      };
    }
  },
  
  methods: {
    handleUpdate(rangeStr) {
      // Note: rangeStr is still in mm/dd/yyyy format from component
      // Need to convert to dd.mm.yyyy for Turkish display
      const [start, end] = rangeStr.split('-');
      this.startDate = this.convertToTurkishFormat(start);
      this.endDate = this.convertToTurkishFormat(end);
    },
    
    convertToTurkishFormat(usDateStr) {
      // Convert mm/dd/yyyy to dd.mm.yyyy
      const [month, day, year] = usDateStr.split('/');
      return `${day}.${month}.${year}`;
    }
  }
};
</script>

commonMistakes.mistake: Not converting dates to Unix timestamps for disabledRange
commonMistakes.why: Component expects Unix timestamps in seconds
commonMistakes.impact: Disabled dates won't work
commonMistakes.fix: Use Math.floor(new Date(date).getTime() / 1000)

commonMistakes.mistake: Creating Date objects in template or computed on every render
commonMistakes.why: Unnecessary object creation affects performance
commonMistakes.impact: Performance degradation
commonMistakes.fix: Move to data() or created() hook

commonMistakes.mistake: Not handling empty date values
commonMistakes.why: v-model can be empty string initially
commonMistakes.impact: Errors when processing date
commonMistakes.fix: Check if value exists before processing

valueFormat.notes: CRITICAL: V1 uses plain object, NOT array like V2. Date format depends on locale setting. Use mm/dd/yyyy for US locale, dd.mm.yyyy for EU/TR locales.

migrationToV2.notes: V2 requires array to support comparison mode

commonMistakes.mistake: Passing array format like V2: [{ startDate, endDate }]
commonMistakes.impact: Component won't render dates, shows empty picker
commonMistakes.fix: Remove array wrapper, use plain object: { startDate, endDate }

commonMistakes.mistake: Passing Date objects instead of strings
commonMistakes.impact: Type error, component may crash
commonMistakes.fix: Convert to string: { startDate: '01/12/2024', endDate: '20/12/2024' }

commonMistakes.mistake: Wrong date format for locale (e.g., mm/dd/yyyy for Turkish locale)
commonMistakes.impact: Date parsing fails, shows invalid dates
commonMistakes.fix: Match format to locale: dd.mm.yyyy for tr-TR, mm/dd/yyyy for en-US

valueFormat.notes: CRITICAL: V1 uses object with Date array values. Keys are display labels. Values MUST be native Date objects, NOT strings.

migrationToV2.v2Format: Array<{ name: string, title: string, startDate: string, endDate: string }>
migrationToV2.transformation: Object.entries(v1CustomRanges).map(([title, dates], i) => ({ name: `custom${i+1}`, title, startDate: formatDateToSlash(dates[0]), endDate: formatDateToSlash(dates[1]) }))
migrationToV2.notes: V2 uses array with mm/dd/yyyy string format

commonMistakes.mistake: Using string dates instead of Date objects: { 'Q4': ['10/01/2024', '12/31/2024'] }
commonMistakes.impact: Component won't render custom ranges, buttons don't appear
commonMistakes.fix: Use Date objects: { 'Q4': [new Date('2024-10-01'), new Date('2024-12-31')] }

commonMistakes.mistake: Passing V2 array format with name/title properties
commonMistakes.impact: Type error, custom ranges won't work
commonMistakes.fix: Use V1 object format with Date arrays

commonMistakes.mistake: Not setting customDateRange prop to true
commonMistakes.impact: Custom ranges won't be displayed even if provided
commonMistakes.fix: Add :custom-date-range="true" to enable custom ranges

valueFormat.notes: CRITICAL: V1 uses Unix timestamps in SECONDS (not milliseconds). Array of two numbers: [start, end]. Dates in this range will be disabled.

migrationToV2.transformation: { startDate: formatDate(new Date(v1[0] * 1000)), endDate: formatDate(new Date(v1[1] * 1000)) }
migrationToV2.notes: V2 uses object with date strings

commonMistakes.mistake: Using milliseconds instead of seconds: [Date.now(), Date.now()]
commonMistakes.impact: Incorrect date range disabled, may disable dates far in future
commonMistakes.fix: Convert to seconds: [Math.floor(Date.now() / 1000), Math.floor(endDate.getTime() / 1000)]

commonMistakes.mistake: Passing Date objects or strings
commonMistakes.impact: Type error, disabled range won't work
commonMistakes.fix: Convert to Unix timestamps in seconds: [date.getTime() / 1000, ...]

commonMistakes.mistake: Using V2 object format: { startDate, endDate }
commonMistakes.impact: Type error, disabled range won't work
commonMistakes.fix: Use array of Unix timestamps: [startTimestamp, endTimestamp]

valueFormat.notes: Maps locale codes to date format strings. Must match format used in value prop. Common formats: mm/dd/yyyy (US), dd.mm.yyyy (EU/TR), dd/mm/yyyy (GB).

commonMistakes.mistake: Not providing 'default' fallback key
commonMistakes.impact: Component may not format dates correctly for unmapped locales
commonMistakes.fix: Always include 'default' key: { 'default': 'dd.mm.yyyy', ... }

commonMistakes.mistake: Format string doesn't match value prop format
commonMistakes.impact: Date parsing/display mismatch, shows wrong dates
commonMistakes.fix: Ensure formatMapping matches value date format

valueFormat.notes: Controls calendar popover position. Renamed to 'calendarPopoverAlign' in V2.
Shows extended set of quick ranges (Last 30 Days, This Month, Last Month, etc.). Replaced with more flexible 'defaultRanges' array in V2.

migrationToV2.notes: V2 uses array for granular control

commonMistakes.mistake: Expecting customRanges to show without setting customDateRange=true
commonMistakes.impact: Custom ranges won't appear
commonMistakes.fix: Set both :custom-date-range="true" and provide :custom-ranges

valueFormat.notes: Enables single date selection mode. When true, only startDate is used. Renamed to 'singleDatePickerStatus' in V2.

commonMistakes.mistake: Still providing endDate when singleDatePicker=true
commonMistakes.impact: endDate is ignored, may cause confusion
commonMistakes.fix: When single mode, only set startDate in value object

update.useCase: Emitted when user selects a date range and clicks apply. V1 always returns string (no comparison support).

migrationToV2.notes: V2 can return array when comparison is active. Must check Array.isArray(payload) in V2 handler.

commonMistakes.mistake: Expecting array payload like V2
commonMistakes.impact: String.split() will fail if checking Array.isArray() first
commonMistakes.fix: V1 always returns string, no array check needed

commonMistakes.mistake: Not updating value prop reactively
commonMistakes.impact: Component won't reflect user selection
commonMistakes.fix: Update startDate/endDate in data() and use computed for value

dateRange.title: Date Range Picker
dateRange.description: Select date range with custom ranges
dateRange.code:
<script setup>
import { ref } from 'vue';

const dateRange = ref('');

const customRanges = {
  'Last 7 Days': [
    new Date(Date.now() - 7 * 24 * 60 * 60 * 1000),
    new Date()
  ],
  'Last 30 Days': [
    new Date(Date.now() - 30 * 24 * 60 * 60 * 1000),
    new Date()
  ],
  'This Month': [
    new Date(new Date().getFullYear(), new Date().getMonth(), 1),
    new Date()
  ]
};
</script>

<template>
  <InDatePicker
    id="range-picker"
    label="Date Range"
    range
    v-model="dateRange"
    :custom-ranges="customRanges"
  />
</template>
