smsTemplateInput.title: SMS Template with Character Limit
smsTemplateInput.description: SMS message with length validation and dynamic content
smsTemplateInput.code:
<script setup>
import { ref } from 'vue';
import { InSuperInput } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

const smsContent = ref('');
const cleanContent = ref('');

const smsAttributes = [
  { label: 'First Name', value: 'first_name', category: 'User' },
  { label: 'Phone', value: 'phone', category: 'User' },
  { label: 'Order ID', value: 'order_id', category: 'Order' },
  { label: 'Total', value: 'total', category: 'Order' }
];

const handlePurify = (sanitized) => {
  cleanContent.value = sanitized;
};
</script>

<template>
  <InSuperInput
    v-model="smsContent"
    label="SMS Message"
    :dynamic-content-support="true"
    :attribute-list="smsAttributes"
    :text-validate-config="{ maxLength: 160 }"
    :character-counter-status="true"
    fall-back-text="Customer"
    fall-back-label="Default if empty"
    @purify="handlePurify"
  />
</template>

emailSubjectInput.title: Email Subject with Strict Validation
emailSubjectInput.description: Email subject line with controlled dynamic content
emailSubjectInput.code:
<script setup>
import { ref, computed } from 'vue';
import { InSuperInput } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

const subject = ref('');
const formSubmitted = ref(false);

const emailAttributes = [
  { label: 'First Name', value: 'first_name' },
  { label: 'Product Name', value: 'product_name' },
  { label: 'Discount', value: 'discount' }
];

const validationState = computed(() => {
  if (!formSubmitted.value) return {};
  
  if (!subject.value) {
    return {
      invalid: true,
      invalidMessage: 'Subject is required'
    };
  }
  
  if (subject.value.length > 100) {
    return {
      warning: true,
      warningMessage: 'Subject exceeds recommended length (100 chars)'
    };
  }
  
  return {};
});
</script>

<template>
  <InSuperInput
    v-model="subject"
    label="Email Subject"
    :dynamic-content-support="true"
    :attribute-list="emailAttributes"
    strict-add-mode
    :text-validate-config="{ required: true, maxLength: 200 }"
    :fall-back-disabled-characters="['<', '>', '&', '\"']"
    v-bind="validationState"
  />
</template>

styling.notes: Dynamic attribute tags are styled with pill/chip design. Fallback modal appears when clicking on a tag to set default value.

implementationPatterns.name: Controlled Email Template
implementationPatterns.description: Email template with strict attribute control and XSS prevention
implementationPatterns.code:
<script setup>
import { ref } from 'vue';
import { InSuperInput } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

const emailBody = ref('');
const sanitizedBody = ref('');

const allowedAttributes = [
  { label: 'Customer Name', value: 'customer_name', category: 'Customer' },
  { label: 'Product Name', value: 'product_name', category: 'Product' },
  { label: 'Order Total', value: 'order_total', category: 'Order' },
  { label: 'Support Link', value: 'support_link', category: 'Links' }
];

const forbiddenChars = ['<', '>', '&', '"', "'", '/'];

const handlePurify = (clean: string) => {
  sanitizedBody.value = clean;
  // Additional server-side validation recommended
};

const handleSubmit = async () => {
  // Use sanitizedBody for API call, not raw emailBody
  await api.saveEmailTemplate({ body: sanitizedBody.value });
};
</script>

<template>
  <InSuperInput
    v-model="emailBody"
    label="Email Body"
    :dynamic-content-support="true"
    :attribute-list="allowedAttributes"
    strict-add-mode
    :fall-back-disabled-characters="forbiddenChars"
    fall-back-label="Default value"
    @purify="handlePurify"
  />
</template>
implementationPatterns.when: Use for email templates where security is critical and only specific attributes are allowed

commonMistakes.mistake: Using array index as tab ID
commonMistakes.why: Indices change when tabs are reordered or removed
commonMistakes.impact: Active tab tracking breaks, wrong tab gets selected after reorder
commonMistakes.fix: Use stable unique identifiers (string or UUID)

commonMistakes.mistake: Forgetting to handle changeOrder event
commonMistakes.why: Tab order changes are not persisted
commonMistakes.impact: Users reorder tabs but changes are lost on refresh
commonMistakes.fix: Listen to changeOrder event and save new order
commonMistakes.example:
// Add handler:
@changeOrder="({ newOrder }) => saveTabs(newOrder)"

commonMistakes.mistake: Using useRouter=true without route property
commonMistakes.why: Component expects route for navigation
commonMistakes.impact: Console warnings, broken navigation
commonMistakes.fix: Either add route to all tabs or set useRouter=false

commonMistakes.mistake: Not truncating long tab names
commonMistakes.why: Long labels break layout on small screens
commonMistakes.impact: Horizontal scrolling, overlapping tabs, poor mobile UX
commonMistakes.fix: Set maxTabDisplayTextLength to appropriate limit
commonMistakes.example:
<InTabs
  :maxTabDisplayTextLength="20"
  :tabsList="tabs"
/>

valueFormat.structure: Array<{ id: string | number; name: string; route?: string; disabled?: boolean; badge?: number; icon?: string; percentage?: number; }>
valueFormat.notes: Required array defining all tabs. Each tab object must have id and name. Optional fields: route (for routing), disabled, badge (notification count), icon, percentage (for progress tabs). The order in array determines tab display order.

commonMistakes.mistake: Missing id or name in tab objects
commonMistakes.why: Component relies on id for tracking and name for display
commonMistakes.impact: Tabs won't render or will show empty labels
commonMistakes.fix: Ensure every tab object has both id and name properties

valueFormat.notes: When true (default), clicking tabs triggers Vue Router navigation using the 'route' property from tabsList. When false, tabs act as simple UI toggles without routing.
valueFormat.example:
true // Enable routing
false // Disable routing for non-navigation tabs

commonMistakes.mistake: Setting useRouter=true without route in tabsList
commonMistakes.why: Routing requires route property on tab objects
commonMistakes.impact: Console warnings or broken navigation
commonMistakes.fix: Either add route to tabs or set useRouter=false

valueFormat.notes: When true, tabs that don't fit horizontally are moved into an overflow dropdown menu (three-dot menu). Useful for responsive designs with many tabs.
valueFormat.example: true // Enable overflow dropdown for tabs

valueFormat.notes: Enables drag-and-drop reordering of tabs. When user drops a tab, emits 'changeOrder' event with new tab order. Useful for customizable dashboards.
valueFormat.example: true // Allow users to reorder tabs

valueFormat.notes: Shows a '+' button to add new tabs. Works with addNewTabFunctionality to determine add behavior (dropdown options or custom modal).

valueFormat.structure: Array<{ label: string; value: string | number; icon?: string; }>
valueFormat.notes: Options shown in dropdown when user clicks '+ Add Tab' button (requires addNewTabActive=true and addNewTabFunctionality='options'). Each option represents a tab type user can add.
Determines behavior of '+ Add Tab' button. 'options': shows dropdown with addTabDropdownOptions. 'custom': emits addNewTab event for custom handling (e.g., open modal).
valueFormat.example:
'options' // Show dropdown
'custom' // Emit event for custom modal

valueFormat.notes: Shows 'Rename' option in tab context menu (right-click or dropdown). When clicked, emits 'rename' event with tab data.
Shows 'Remove' option in tab context menu. Default is true. When clicked, emits 'removeTab' or 'delete' event depending on useEmitForRemove.
Shows 'Duplicate' option in tab context menu. When clicked, emits 'duplicate' event with tab data to clone.
Applies box/card styling to tabs instead of default underline style. Creates visually distinct rectangular tabs.
Maximum character length for tab labels before truncation. Set to 0 (default) for no truncation. Truncated text shows full label on hover.
valueFormat.example: 20 // Truncate tab names longer than 20 chars

click.description: Emitted when a tab is clicked
click.payload: { id: string | number; name: string; route?: string; }
click.when: User clicks on a tab. Fired before route navigation if useRouter=true.

changeOrder.description: Emitted when user reorders tabs via drag-and-drop
changeOrder.when: User drops a tab in new position (requires draggable=true). Use to persist new tab order.

addNewTab.description: Emitted when user clicks '+ Add Tab' button with custom functionality
addNewTab.when: User clicks add button and addNewTabFunctionality='custom'. Use to show custom modal/form.

removeTab.description: Emitted when user removes a tab
removeTab.payload: { id: string | number; name: string; index: number; }
removeTab.when: User clicks remove option in tab menu (requires removeOption=true).

rename.description: Emitted when user clicks rename option
rename.when: User clicks rename in tab menu (requires renameOption=true). Use to show rename dialog.

duplicate.description: Emitted when user duplicates a tab
duplicate.when: User clicks duplicate option (requires duplicateOption=true). Use to clone tab with new ID.

bestPractices.title: Limit Active Tab Count
bestPractices.description: Keep visible tabs to 5-7 maximum, use dropdownTabs for overflow
bestPractices.code:
<InTabs
  :tabsList="allTabs"
  :dropdownTabs="true"
/>
bestPractices.reasoning: Too many visible tabs cause cognitive overload and UI crowding. Overflow dropdown keeps interface clean while maintaining access to all tabs.

bestPractices.title: Always Provide Unique IDs
bestPractices.description: Use stable, unique identifiers for tab IDs, not array indices
bestPractices.reasoning: Stable IDs ensure correct tab tracking when reordering, adding, or removing tabs. Array indices break when tabs are rearranged.

bestPractices.title: Disable Navigation During Loading
bestPractices.description: Temporarily disable tabs during async operations to prevent race conditions
bestPractices.code:
<InTabs
  :tabsList="tabs.map(t => ({ ...t, disabled: isLoading }))"
/>
bestPractices.reasoning: Prevents users from switching tabs mid-operation, which could cause data inconsistency or incomplete saves.

bestPractices.title: Use Badge Numbers Sparingly
bestPractices.description: Only show badges for actionable notifications, not just counts
bestPractices.reasoning: Badges should indicate items requiring user attention. Overuse reduces their effectiveness and creates visual noise.

performanceNotes.description: Badge counts that update frequently can cause excessive re-renders
performanceNotes.recommendation: Debounce or throttle badge count updates. Use computed properties with proper dependencies.
performanceNotes.impact: High: Constant badge updates can make tabs feel sluggish

performanceNotes.description: Don't render all tab content simultaneously
performanceNotes.recommendation: Use v-if or dynamic components to render only active tab content. Use keep-alive if switching between tabs should preserve state.
performanceNotes.impact: Medium: Pre-rendering all tabs increases initial load time

performanceNotes.description: Rendering 20+ tabs can slow down tab bar
performanceNotes.recommendation: Enable dropdownTabs to hide overflow tabs. Consider if that many tabs indicates a UX problem (maybe use nested navigation instead).
performanceNotes.impact: Medium: Large tab lists affect render performance

accessibilityNotes.description: Tab component should support arrow key navigation between tabs
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Ensure users can navigate tabs with Left/Right arrows and activate with Enter/Space. Test with keyboard only.

accessibilityNotes.description: Tab action buttons (rename, remove, duplicate) need accessible labels
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Ensure dropdown menu options have proper aria-labels. Screen reader should announce 'Rename Dashboard tab' not just 'Rename'.

accessibilityNotes.description: Users should understand why a tab is disabled
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Use tooltips or aria-describedby to explain disabled state. Example: 'Complete Step 1 to unlock Step 2'.

accessibilityNotes.description: Focus should move to tab content after selection
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: When tab changes, focus should move to first interactive element in tab panel for keyboard users.

basicTabs.title: Basic Tab Navigation
basicTabs.code:
<template>
  <InTabs
    :tabsList="tabs"
    :useRouter="true"
    @click="handleTabClick"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
const tabs = ref([
  { id: 'overview', name: 'Overview', route: '/overview' },
  { id: 'analytics', name: 'Analytics', route: '/analytics', badge: 3 },
  { id: 'settings', name: 'Settings', route: '/settings' }
]);

const handleTabClick = (tab) => {
  console.log('Tab clicked:', tab.name);
};
</script>

draggableTabs.title: Draggable Tabs with Persistence
draggableTabs.description: Allow users to reorder tabs and save order
draggableTabs.code:
<template>
  <InTabs
    :tabsList="tabs"
    :draggable="true"
    :useRouter="false"
    @changeOrder="saveTabOrder"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
const tabs = ref([
  { id: 1, name: 'Dashboard' },
  { id: 2, name: 'Reports' },
  { id: 3, name: 'Users' }
]);

const saveTabOrder = ({ newOrder }) => {
  tabs.value = newOrder;
  localStorage.setItem('tabOrder', JSON.stringify(newOrder));
};

// Load saved order on mount
onMounted(() => {
  const saved = localStorage.getItem('tabOrder');
  if (saved) tabs.value = JSON.parse(saved);
});
</script>

dynamicTabs.title: Dynamic Tabs with Add/Remove
dynamicTabs.description: Allow users to add and remove tabs
dynamicTabs.code:
<template>
  <InTabs
    :tabsList="tabs"
    :addNewTabActive="true"
    :addNewTabFunctionality="'options'"
    :addTabDropdownOptions="addOptions"
    :removeOption="true"
    @addNewTab="handleAddTab"
    @removeTab="handleRemoveTab"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
const tabs = ref([
  { id: 1, name: 'Home' }
]);

const addOptions = [
  { label: 'Add Chart', value: 'chart' },
  { label: 'Add Table', value: 'table' }
];

let nextId = 2;
const handleAddTab = (option) => {
  tabs.value.push({
    id: nextId++,
    name: option.label,
    type: option.value
  });
};

const handleRemoveTab = ({ id }) => {
  tabs.value = tabs.value.filter(tab => tab.id !== id);
};
</script>

styling.notes: Box-style tabs (boxStyle=true) have distinct rectangular appearance with borders. Default style uses underline for active tab.

implementationPatterns.name: Responsive Tab Overflow
implementationPatterns.description: Handle many tabs gracefully on small screens using dropdown overflow
implementationPatterns.code:
<InTabs
  :tabsList="manyTabs"
  :dropdownTabs="true"
  :maxTabDisplayTextLength="20"
/>
implementationPatterns.when: You have 5+ tabs or tab names are long. Prevents horizontal scrolling and layout breaking.
pros: Clean UI even with many tabs
cons: Tabs in dropdown are less discoverable
Requires extra click for overflow tabs

implementationPatterns.name: Controlled Tab State (Non-Router)
implementationPatterns.description: Manually control active tab without routing, useful for sub-navigation
implementationPatterns.code:
<template>
  <InTabs
    :tabsList="tabs"
    :useRouter="false"
    @click="activeTab = $event.id"
  />
  <component :is="tabComponents[activeTab]" />
</template>

<script setup>
const activeTab = ref('overview');
const tabComponents = {
  overview: OverviewTab,
  details: DetailsTab
};
</script>
implementationPatterns.when: Tabs control content within a page/modal, not entire routes. Common in settings panels, wizards, or detail views.

implementationPatterns.name: Persistent Tab Customization
implementationPatterns.description: Save user's tab order, added tabs, and preferences to localStorage/backend
implementationPatterns.code:
<template>
  <InTabs
    :tabsList="userTabs"
    :draggable="true"
    :addNewTabActive="true"
    @changeOrder="saveTabs"
    @addNewTab="saveTabs"
    @removeTab="saveTabs"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
const userTabs = ref([]);

// Load on mount
onMounted(async () => {
  const saved = await api.getUserTabs();
  userTabs.value = saved || defaultTabs;
});

const saveTabs = () => {
  api.saveUserTabs(userTabs.value);
};
</script>
implementationPatterns.when: Building customizable dashboards where users can personalize their workflow. Common in analytics platforms, CRM tools.

useCases.title: Multi-Section Dashboard Navigation
useCases.description: Primary navigation between major dashboard sections with route-based tabs
useCases.example: Marketing platform with tabs for Campaigns, Audiences, Analytics, Reports, and Settings. Each tab navigates to different route with its own sub-pages.

useCases.title: Report Builder with Dynamic Tabs
useCases.description: Allow users to add multiple report tabs, each with different data views
useCases.example: Analytics dashboard where users can add chart tabs, table tabs, or metric cards. Tabs are draggable, renameable, and removable for custom layouts.

useCases.title: Multi-Step Form Wizard
useCases.description: Progress indicator showing completion status for each step
useCases.example: Onboarding flow with Account Setup → Profile → Preferences → Complete. Box-style tabs with percentage indicators show progress. Previous steps are clickable, future steps are disabled.

useCases.title: Settings Panel Organization
useCases.description: Organize complex settings into categorized tabs without route changes
useCases.example: Account settings with General, Security, Notifications, Integrations tabs. Uses useRouter=false to keep settings in one route with tab-based content switching.

examples.title: Status Tags in Data Table
examples.description: Show campaign or item status with colored tags
examples.code:
<template>
  <InDataTableV2 :data="campaigns" :columns="columns">
    <template #status="{ row }">
      <InTagsText
        :text="row.statusText"
        :value="row.status"
        :type="getStatusType(row.status)"
        @click="filterByStatus"
      />
    </template>
  </InDataTableV2>
</template>

<script setup lang="ts">
import { ref } from 'vue';

const campaigns = ref([
  { id: 1, name: 'Summer Sale', status: 'active', statusText: 'Active' },
  { id: 2, name: 'Black Friday', status: 'scheduled', statusText: 'Scheduled' },
  { id: 3, name: 'Old Campaign', status: 'paused', statusText: 'Paused' },
  { id: 4, name: 'Failed Test', status: 'failed', statusText: 'Failed' }
]);

const getStatusType = (status: string) => {
  const typeMap = {
    active: 'success',
    scheduled: 'info',
    paused: 'warning',
    failed: 'danger',
    draft: 'default'
  };
  return typeMap[status] || 'default';
};

const filterByStatus = (tag) => {
  console.log('Filter campaigns by status:', tag.value);
  // Apply filter
};
</script>

commonMistakes.mistake: Not providing unique values for tags
commonMistakes.why: value prop is used to identify which tag was clicked
commonMistakes.impact: Can't distinguish which tag was clicked in event handler
commonMistakes.fix: Ensure each tag has unique value (ID, status code, category slug)

commonMistakes.mistake: Using inconsistent type colors for same status
commonMistakes.why: Confuses users about what colors mean
commonMistakes.impact: Users can't rely on color coding, reduces UX quality
commonMistakes.fix: Create status-to-type mapping and use consistently

commonMistakes.mistake: Not handling long text
commonMistakes.why: User-generated category names can be very long
commonMistakes.impact: Tags overflow, break grid/flex layouts
commonMistakes.fix: Set maxWidth and optionally add tooltip for full text

commonMistakes.mistake: Making read-only tags look clickable
commonMistakes.why: Users expect clickable appearance means clickable
commonMistakes.impact: Frustrating UX when tags don't respond to clicks
commonMistakes.fix: Set disable=true for non-interactive tags or remove @click

valueFormat.notes: Display text shown on the tag. Keep concise (1-3 words). This is the visible label users see. Required prop.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using long text without setting maxWidth
commonMistakes.why: Long text can break layout without truncation
commonMistakes.impact: Tags overflow, break UI alignment
commonMistakes.fix: Set maxWidth to truncate long text with ellipsis

valueFormat.notes: Unique identifier for the tag. Used in click events and for tracking which tag was interacted with. Must be unique within tag group. Required prop.
Visual variant determining color scheme. Common values: 'default' (gray), 'primary' (blue), 'success' (green), 'warning' (orange), 'danger' (red), 'info' (cyan). Maps to semantic meanings.
valueFormat.example:
'default' // Neutral gray tag
'success' // Green for positive status
'warning' // Orange for caution
'danger' // Red for errors/critical
'primary' // Blue for emphasis
'info' // Cyan for informational

valueFormat.notes: When true, tag appears grayed out and click event is disabled. Use for inactive/unavailable states.
When true (default), shows an icon based on tag type. Each type has a default icon. Set false for text-only tags.
valueFormat.example:
true // Show type-based icon (default)
false // Text-only, no icon

valueFormat.notes: Maximum width in pixels for tag text. When text exceeds this width, it's truncated with ellipsis (...). Null (default) means no truncation. Use for consistent tag sizing.
valueFormat.example:
null // No truncation (default)
100 // Max 100px wide
150 // Max 150px wide

valueFormat.notes: When true (default), sanitizes text to prevent XSS attacks. Should always be true when text comes from user input or untrusted sources.
valueFormat.example:
true // Sanitize text (default - recommended)
false // No sanitization (use only for trusted content)

click.description: Emitted when user clicks the tag (only if disable=false)
click.payload: { text: string; value: string | number; type: string; }
click.when: User clicks on an enabled tag. Commonly used for filtering, navigation, or tag removal.

helperFunctions.name: createStatusTagConfig
helperFunctions.description: Factory function to create consistent status tag configurations

helperFunctions.name: useTagFilters
helperFunctions.description: Composable for managing tag-based filtering

parameters.name: items
parameters.description: Reactive array of items to filter

helperFunctions.returnType: { activeFilter: Ref<string>, filteredItems: ComputedRef<Array>, setFilter: Function, clearFilter: Function, isActive: Function }

bestPractices.title: Use Semantic Type Colors Consistently
bestPractices.description: Map tag types to consistent meanings across the app
bestPractices.code:
// Good - Consistent mapping:
success: 'active', 'completed', 'approved'
warning: 'pending', 'paused', 'review'
danger: 'failed', 'rejected', 'error'
info: 'scheduled', 'processing'
default: 'draft', 'inactive'

// Bad - Inconsistent:
success: sometimes active, sometimes pending
bestPractices.reasoning: Consistent color coding helps users quickly understand status. Changing color meanings confuses users and reduces UX quality.

bestPractices.title: Set maxWidth for User-Generated Content
bestPractices.description: Prevent layout breaking from long category names
bestPractices.code:
// Good:
<InTagsText
  :text="userCategory"
  :maxWidth="150"
/>

// Bad:
<InTagsText :text="userCategory" /> // Can break layout
bestPractices.reasoning: User-generated content is unpredictable. Long category names break layouts without truncation. Always set maxWidth for UGC.

bestPractices.title: Disable Tags When Interaction Isn't Allowed
bestPractices.description: Use disable prop when users shouldn't interact with tag
bestPractices.reasoning: Visual feedback (grayed out) tells users they can't interact. Better UX than clickable tags that show error on click.

bestPractices.title: Keep preventXss=true for Safety
bestPractices.description: Always sanitize user-generated tag text
bestPractices.code:
// Good (default):
<InTagsText
  :text="userInput"
  :preventXss="true" // default
/>

// Unsafe:
<InTagsText
  :text="userInput"
  :preventXss="false" // XSS risk
bestPractices.reasoning: preventXss=true is default for security. Only disable for trusted, static content. User input must always be sanitized.

performanceNotes.description: Large lists of tags (100+) can impact render performance
performanceNotes.recommendation: Use virtual scrolling for very long tag lists. Limit visible tags to 20-30 with 'Show More' pagination.
performanceNotes.impact: Low: Only affects pages with 100+ tags

performanceNotes.description: preventXss sanitization has small performance cost per tag
performanceNotes.recommendation: Keep preventXss=true (default) for safety. For static, trusted content only, can set false if performance critical.
performanceNotes.impact: Very Low: Negligible unless hundreds of tags

accessibilityNotes.description: Clickable tags must be keyboard accessible
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Ensure tags are focusable via Tab key and activatable with Enter/Space. Component should handle this by default.

accessibilityNotes.description: Don't rely only on color to convey information
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Include text labels along with colors. For example, not just red tag, but red tag with 'Failed' text.

accessibilityNotes.description: Tag text must have sufficient contrast against background
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Ensure 4.5:1 contrast ratio. Test all tag types (success, warning, danger, etc.) for contrast compliance.
accessibilityNotes.example: Use design system colors that meet WCAG AA standards

accessibilityNotes.description: Screen readers need to know tag is disabled
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: When disable=true, ensure aria-disabled='true' is set so screen readers announce disabled state.

clickableFilterTag.title: Clickable Filter Tag
clickableFilterTag.description: Tag that filters content when clicked

styling.notes: Tag colors are semantic: green=success, red=danger, orange=warning, blue=primary, gray=default. Icons are automatically chosen based on type.

implementationPatterns.name: Interactive Filter Tags
implementationPatterns.description: Use tags as clickable filters with visual active state
implementationPatterns.code:
<InTagsText
  v-for="tag in filters"
  :key="tag.value"
  :text="tag.text"
  :value="tag.value"
  :type="activeFilter === tag.value ? 'primary' : 'default'"
  @click="(t) => activeFilter = t.value"
/>
implementationPatterns.when: Users need to filter content by categories, statuses, or tags. Common in dashboards, content lists, and search results.
pros: Clear visual feedback for active filter
cons: Limited to single selection without custom logic
Can be cluttered with many tags

implementationPatterns.when: Just showing status/category without interaction. Common in tables, cards, and detail views.
cons: Might look clickable if disable styling unclear

implementationPatterns.name: Truncated Label Tags

// With tooltip on hover
<InTooltipV2 :text="longCategoryName">
  <InTagsText
    :text="longCategoryName"
    :value="categoryId"
    :maxWidth="120"
  />
</InTooltipV2>
implementationPatterns.when: Category or label names vary in length and can break layout. Common in user-generated content.

useCases.example: Blog or content listing with category tags at top: 'All', 'Tech', 'Marketing', 'Sales'. Clicking a tag filters the list. Active tag highlighted in blue.

useCases.example: User profile showing role tags: 'Admin' (red), 'Editor' (orange), 'Viewer' (blue). Admins can click to modify roles, others see disabled tags.

examples.title: Complete Registration Form
examples.description: Multi-field registration form with validation, icons, and different input types

examples.title: Advanced Search Filter Panel
examples.description: Search interface with multiple input types, filters, and real-time results

commonMistakes.mistake: Using same ID for multiple inputs
commonMistakes.why: Violates HTML specification and breaks label associations
commonMistakes.impact: Clicking labels focuses wrong inputs, accessibility tools malfunction, form data may conflict
commonMistakes.fix: Generate unique IDs per input using component key, index, or UUID generators

commonMistakes.mistake: Disabling XSS protection for user inputs
commonMistakes.why: Creates critical security vulnerability allowing malicious script injection
commonMistakes.impact: Attackers can steal sessions, hijack accounts, steal data, or inject malware
commonMistakes.fix: Always keep preventXss: true (default) for any user-generated content

commonMistakes.mistake: Not validating on blur, validating on every keystroke instead
commonMistakes.why: Showing errors while user is still typing is frustrating and annoying
commonMistakes.impact: Poor UX, users see "invalid email" error before finishing typing their email
commonMistakes.fix: Use @blur for validation, optionally clear errors on @input

commonMistakes.mistake: Not debouncing search inputs
commonMistakes.why: Triggers API call on every keystroke, causing excessive server requests
commonMistakes.impact: Performance issues, increased server costs, rate limiting, slow UI
commonMistakes.fix: Debounce @input event by 300-500ms, execute immediately on @enter

commonMistakes.mistake: Using type='number' without min/max or allowDecimal settings
commonMistakes.why: Users can enter negative numbers, decimals when not wanted, or unrealistic values
commonMistakes.impact: Invalid data like negative quantities, decimal counts, or ages over 200
commonMistakes.fix: Always set min, and configure allowDecimal based on use case

commonMistakes.mistake: Forgetting autoComplete attributes
commonMistakes.why: Browsers can't autofill, forcing users to manually type repetitive information
commonMistakes.impact: Poor UX, slower form completion, higher abandonment rates
commonMistakes.fix: Add appropriate autoComplete values for common fields
commonMistakes.example:
// WRONG - no autocomplete hints
<InTextInput type="email" />
<InTextInput type="password" />

// CORRECT - enables browser autofill
<InTextInput type="email" autoComplete="email" />
<InTextInput type="password" autoComplete="current-password" />
<InTextInput type="text" autoComplete="given-name" /> <!-- First name -->
<InTextInput type="tel" autoComplete="tel" />

valueFormat.notes: Unique identifier for the input element. Required for accessibility (label association), form submission, and DOM manipulation. Must be unique within the page.
valueFormat.example:
// Form field IDs
'user-email'
'billing-address'
'search-query'

// Unique per instance
`input-${uniqueId()}`
`field-${index}-${name}`

commonMistakes.mistake: Using duplicate IDs across multiple inputs
commonMistakes.why: Violates HTML spec and breaks label associations
commonMistakes.impact: Labels click wrong inputs, accessibility tools malfunction, form data conflicts
commonMistakes.fix: Generate unique IDs using component key, index, or UUID

valueFormat.notes: Name attribute for form submission. Used when submitting forms via standard POST/GET or when using FormData. Groups radio buttons and identifies fields in form data.
valueFormat.example:
// Form field names
'email'
'first_name'
'billing[address]'

// Nested form data
'user[profile][bio]'
'settings[notifications][email]'

valueFormat.notes: Current input value. Use v-model for two-way binding. Supports both string and number types. For type='number', prefer number values for proper validation.
HTML input type. Controls validation, keyboard on mobile, and browser behavior. Common types: text, email, password, number, tel, url, search, date, time.
Visual theme/color scheme for the input. Affects border, background, and hover states.
Enables icon display inside the input. Requires iconName prop to specify which icon. Icon can be positioned left or right via iconPosition.
Icon identifier from the design system icon library. Only effective when withIcon is true. Use @iconClick event to make icon interactive.
valueFormat.example:
// Common icons
iconName="search"
iconName="email"
iconName="lock"
iconName="user"
iconName="calendar"
iconName="phone"
iconName="link"
iconName="visibility" // For password toggle
iconName="clear" // For clear button

valueFormat.notes: Position of the icon within the input field.
Enables suffix text display after the input value. Use suffix prop to specify the text. Common for units (%, $, kg, etc.).
Text to display as suffix when withSuffix is true. Appears after the input value, typically for units or currency symbols.
valueFormat.example:
suffix="%" // Percentage
suffix="$" // Dollar
suffix="€" // Euro
suffix="kg" // Kilogram
suffix="px" // Pixels
suffix="days" // Time unit

valueFormat.notes: Prefix text or symbol to display before the input value. When boolean true, uses default. When string, displays that text. Common for currency symbols.
valueFormat.example:
// Enable default prefix
:prefix="true"

// Custom prefix text
prefix="$"
prefix="+1" // Phone country code
prefix="https://"
prefix="@" // Username

valueFormat.notes: For type='number', allows decimal point input. When false, restricts to integers only. Works with allowComma to control decimal separator.
valueFormat.example:
// Integer only (quantity, count)
:allowDecimal="false"
type="number"

// Allow decimals (price, weight)
:allowDecimal="true"
type="number"
v-model.number="price"

valueFormat.notes: Allows comma as decimal separator (European format: 1,5 instead of 1.5). Only relevant when allowDecimal is true.
Maximum number of characters allowed. Browser enforces this limit. Shows character counter if component supports it.
Minimum value for type='number'. Browser validates on form submission. Use for quantities, ages, prices, etc.
HTML autocomplete attribute. Controls browser autofill behavior. Use 'off' to disable, or specific values for enhanced autofill (email, name, tel, etc.).
For type='file', specifies accepted file types. Comma-separated MIME types or file extensions. Filters file picker dialog.
Dimensions for skeleton loader when skeletonStatus is true. Controls width and height of the skeleton placeholder.
Tooltip text shown on label hover. Provides additional context or help text for the input field.
valueFormat.example:
label="API Key"
labelTooltip="Your secret API key from the dashboard settings"

label="Tax ID"
labelTooltip="Enter your business tax identification number"

label="Webhook URL"
labelTooltip="HTTPS endpoint that will receive webhook events"

valueFormat.notes: Enables XSS (Cross-Site Scripting) prevention by sanitizing input value. Default is true. Only disable for trusted admin inputs.

commonMistakes.mistake: Disabling preventXss for user-generated content
commonMistakes.why: Creates XSS vulnerability allowing script injection
commonMistakes.impact: Critical security risk - attackers can steal data, hijack sessions, or deface pages
commonMistakes.fix: Always keep preventXss: true for any user input. Only disable for trusted admin-only fields.

input.description: Emitted on every input change (keystroke, paste, etc.)
input.payload: Event - Native input event with event.target.value
input.when: User types, pastes, or programmatically changes value

change.description: Emitted when input loses focus after value changed
change.when: Input value changed and user blurs/tabs away from field

focus.when: User clicks input or tabs into it

blur.when: User clicks away or tabs out of input

enter.description: Emitted when Enter key is pressed
enter.when: User presses Enter/Return while input is focused

keyup.when: User releases any key while input is focused

click.when: User clicks on the input field

iconClick.description: Emitted when icon is clicked (requires withIcon: true)
iconClick.when: User clicks the icon inside the input

helperFunctions.name: useFormField
helperFunctions.description: Composable for managing individual form field state with validation and error handling
parameters: validator?: (value: T) => string - Optional validation function that returns error message or empty string
helperFunctions.returnType: { value, error, touched, dirty, isValid, showError, validate, handleBlur, handleInput, reset }

helperFunctions.name: createPasswordValidator
helperFunctions.description: Factory function to create password validators with configurable strength requirements
parameters: requirements: PasswordRequirements - Configuration object for password strength rules
helperFunctions.returnType: (password: string) => string - Validator function that returns error message or empty string

helperFunctions.name: useSearchInput
helperFunctions.description: Composable for search inputs with debouncing, loading state, and clear functionality
parameters: searchFn: (query: string) => Promise<T[]> - Async function that performs search and returns results
options: { debounceMs?: number, minLength?: number } - Configuration options
helperFunctions.returnType: { query, results, loading, error, hasQuery, hasResults, handleInput, executeImmediate, clear }

bestPractices.title: Always Provide Unique IDs
bestPractices.description: Generate unique id for each input to ensure proper label association and accessibility
bestPractices.reasoning: Unique IDs prevent conflicts, enable proper label clicking, and ensure screen readers correctly associate labels with inputs

bestPractices.title: Use Appropriate Input Types
bestPractices.description: Choose the correct type prop for better validation and mobile keyboard optimization
bestPractices.reasoning: Improves mobile UX with optimized keyboards, enables browser validation, and triggers relevant autofill suggestions

bestPractices.title: Implement Proper Validation
bestPractices.description: Validate on blur for better UX, show clear error messages, and prevent invalid form submission
bestPractices.reasoning: Blur validation avoids annoying users while typing, clear messages help correct errors, and prevents bad data submission

bestPractices.title: Debounce Search and Real-time Inputs
bestPractices.description: Add debouncing to search inputs and live-update fields to reduce API calls and improve performance
bestPractices.reasoning: Prevents excessive API calls, reduces server load and costs, improves performance, and maintains responsive UX

performanceNotes.description: For inputs triggering expensive operations (API calls, heavy computations), debounce the @input event handler
performanceNotes.recommendation: Use useDebounceFn with 300-500ms delay for search, 1000ms+ for autosave. Execute immediately on @enter or @blur for better UX.
performanceNotes.impact: Can reduce API calls by 90%+ and eliminate UI lag during typing

performanceNotes.description: Using v-model.number ensures values are stored as numbers, not strings
performanceNotes.recommendation: Always use v-model.number with type='number' to avoid string-to-number conversions in your code
performanceNotes.impact: Prevents unnecessary type coercion and comparison bugs (e.g., '10' > '9' is false as strings)

performanceNotes.description: Complex regex or async validation on every keystroke can cause lag
performanceNotes.recommendation: Validate on @blur for most fields. For real-time validation, debounce by 300ms or use simple checks during typing, complex checks on blur.
performanceNotes.impact: Eliminates typing lag and improves perceived performance

accessibilityNotes.description: Every input must have an associated label for screen readers
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Always provide unique id and use label prop. The component handles for attribute automatically. For hidden labels, use aria-label.
accessibilityNotes.example:
<!-- Visible label (preferred) -->
<InTextInput id="email" name="email" label="Email Address" />

<!-- Hidden label with aria-label -->
<InTextInput
  id="search"
  name="search"
  :withLabel="false"
  aria-label="Search products"
/>

accessibilityNotes.description: Validation errors must be announced to screen reader users
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Use invalid and invalidMessage props. Component announces errors via aria-describedby. For critical errors, add aria-live region.
accessibilityNotes.example: {{ criticalError }}

accessibilityNotes.description: Required fields must be clearly indicated visually and programmatically
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Use HTML5 required attribute and visual indicator (asterisk). Announce requirement in label or aria-label.
accessibilityNotes.example:
<InTextInput
  id="email"
  name="email"
  label="Email Address *"
  required
  aria-required="true"
/>

accessibilityNotes.description: All input functionality must be keyboard accessible
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Component is keyboard accessible by default. Ensure icon actions work with Enter/Space. Tab order should be logical.
accessibilityNotes.example:
<!-- Icon click accessible via keyboard -->
<InTextInput
  :withIcon="true"
  iconName="clear"
  @iconClick="handleClear"
  @keydown.enter="handleClear" <!-- Also trigger on Enter -->
/>

basicInput.title: Basic Text Input
basicInput.description: Simple text input with label and validation
basicInput.code:
<template>
  <InTextInput
    id="user-email"
    name="email"
    v-model="email"
    type="email"
    label="Email Address"
    placeholder="Enter your email"
    :invalid="emailError !== ''"
    :invalidMessage="emailError"
    @blur="validateEmail"
  />
</template>

<script setup lang="ts">
import { ref } from 'vue';
import { InTextInput } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

const email = ref('');
const emailError = ref('');

const validateEmail = () => {
  if (!email.value) {
    emailError.value = 'Email is required';
  } else if (!/^[^\s@]+@[^\s@]+\.[^\s@]+$/.test(email.value)) {
    emailError.value = 'Invalid email format';
  } else {
    emailError.value = '';
  }
};
</script>

<script setup lang="ts">
import { ref } from 'vue';
import { InTextInput } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';
import { useDebounceFn } from '@vueuse/core';

const searchQuery = ref('');

const performSearch = (query: string) => {
  console.log('Searching for:', query);
  // API call here
};

const handleSearch = useDebounceFn(() => {
  if (searchQuery.value.length >= 3) {
    performSearch(searchQuery.value);
  }
}, 300);

const executeSearch = () => {
  if (searchQuery.value) {
    performSearch(searchQuery.value);
  }
};
</script>

implementationPatterns.name: Form Field with Validation Pattern
implementationPatterns.description: Standard input with label, validation, and error messaging
implementationPatterns.when: Building forms with user input validation
implementationPatterns.code:
<template>
  <InTextInput
    :id="fieldId"
    :name="name"
    v-model="modelValue"
    :type="type"
    :label="label"
    :placeholder="placeholder"
    :invalid="!!error"
    :invalidMessage="error"
    :required="required"
    @blur="validate"
  />
</template>

<script setup lang="ts">
import { ref, computed } from 'vue';
import { InTextInput } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

interface Props {
  modelValue: string;
  name: string;
  label: string;
  type?: string;
  placeholder?: string;
  required?: boolean;
  validator?: (value: string) => string;
}

const props = withDefaults(defineProps<Props>(), {
  type: 'text',
  placeholder: '',
  required: false
});

const emit = defineEmits(['update:modelValue']);

const error = ref('');
const fieldId = computed(() => `field-${props.name}`);

const validate = () => {
  if (props.required && !props.modelValue) {
    error.value = `${props.label} is required`;
    return;
  }
  
  if (props.validator) {
    error.value = props.validator(props.modelValue);
  } else {
    error.value = '';
  }
};
</script>
pros: Easy to extend with custom validators
cons: May be overkill for simple forms

implementationPatterns.name: Search Input with Debouncing Pattern
implementationPatterns.description: Search field that debounces input to reduce API calls
implementationPatterns.when: Implementing search with real-time results or autocomplete
implementationPatterns.code:
<template>
  <InTextInput
    id="search"
    name="search"
    v-model="searchQuery"
    type="search"
    placeholder="Search..."
    :withIcon="true"
    iconName="search"
    autoComplete="off"
    @input="handleSearchDebounced"
    @enter="performImmediateSearch"
  />
</template>

<script setup lang="ts">
import { ref } from 'vue';
import { InTextInput } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';
import { useDebounceFn } from '@vueuse/core';

const searchQuery = ref('');

const performSearch = async (query: string) => {
  if (query.length < 3) return;
  console.log('Searching:', query);
  // API call here
};

const handleSearchDebounced = useDebounceFn(() => {
  performSearch(searchQuery.value);
}, 300);

const performImmediateSearch = () => {
  performSearch(searchQuery.value);
};
</script>
cons: May feel sluggish on slow networks

implementationPatterns.name: Dynamic Input with Icon Actions Pattern
implementationPatterns.description: Input with interactive icon for actions like clear, toggle visibility, or submit
implementationPatterns.when: Password visibility toggle, clear button, or inline actions needed
implementationPatterns.code:
<template>
  <InTextInput
    :id="id"
    :name="name"
    v-model="localValue"
    :type="inputType"
    :label="label"
    :placeholder="placeholder"
    :withIcon="true"
    :iconName="iconName"
    iconPosition="right"
    @iconClick="handleIconClick"
  />
</template>

<script setup lang="ts">
import { ref, computed } from 'vue';
import { InTextInput } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

interface Props {
  id: string;
  name: string;
  modelValue: string;
  label: string;
  placeholder?: string;
  action: 'clear' | 'toggle-password' | 'submit';
}

const props = defineProps<Props>();
const emit = defineEmits(['update:modelValue', 'submit']);

const localValue = computed({
  get: () => props.modelValue,
  set: (value) => emit('update:modelValue', value)
});

const showPassword = ref(false);

const inputType = computed(() => {
  if (props.action === 'toggle-password') {
    return showPassword.value ? 'text' : 'password';
  }
  return 'text';
});

const iconName = computed(() => {
  switch (props.action) {
    case 'clear':
      return 'close';
    case 'toggle-password':
      return showPassword.value ? 'visibility_off' : 'visibility';
    case 'submit':
      return 'arrow_forward';
    default:
      return 'search';
  }
});

const handleIconClick = () => {
  switch (props.action) {
    case 'clear':
      localValue.value = '';
      break;
    case 'toggle-password':
      showPassword.value = !showPassword.value;
      break;
    case 'submit':
      emit('submit', localValue.value);
      break;
  }
};
</script>
cons: Icon may not be obvious to all users
May conflict with browser autofill UI

useCases.title: User Registration Forms
useCases.description: Collect user information with validation for username, email, password, and personal details
useCases.example: Sign-up forms requiring email validation, password strength checking, age verification, and phone number formatting. Use type='email' for email fields, type='password' for passwords with visibility toggle, and type='number' with min for age.

useCases.title: Search and Filter Interfaces
useCases.description: Search inputs with real-time filtering across product catalogs, user lists, or documentation
useCases.example: E-commerce product search with debounced autocomplete, admin dashboards with user search, knowledge bases with content search. Use type='search', withIcon for search icon, and debounce @input events.

useCases.title: Settings and Configuration Panels
useCases.description: Application settings requiring various input types like API keys, URLs, numeric thresholds, and text values
useCases.example: API key inputs with prefix/suffix for format guidance, webhook URL configuration with type='url', timeout settings with type='number' and unit suffix, feature toggles with text explanations.

useCases.title: Data Entry Forms
useCases.description: Business forms for invoices, orders, inventory management requiring structured input
useCases.example: Invoice forms with price inputs (prefix='$', allowDecimal=true), quantity fields (type='number', allowDecimal=false), SKU/product codes with maxLength, discount percentages with suffix='%'.

useCases.title: Login and Authentication
useCases.description: Secure login forms with username/email and password fields with proper autocomplete
useCases.example: Login pages with autoComplete='email' and autoComplete='current-password', registration with autoComplete='new-password', password reset flows with validation feedback.

useCases.title: Profile and Account Management
useCases.description: User profile editing with personal information, contact details, and preferences
useCases.example: Profile pages with name fields, email (type='email'), phone (type='tel' with prefix), bio/description with maxLength, social media URLs (type='url'), age/birthday (type='number' with min).

commonMistakes.mistake: Not auto-dismissing toasts
commonMistakes.why: Toasts should be temporary, self-dismissing notifications
commonMistakes.impact: Toasts stack up on screen, clutter interface
commonMistakes.fix: Always set timeout to dismiss toast after 3-5 seconds

commonMistakes.mistake: Using toasts for critical information
commonMistakes.why: Toasts auto-dismiss, users might miss important info
commonMistakes.impact: Critical information lost, users confused
commonMistakes.fix: Use modals for critical info that requires acknowledgment

commonMistakes.mistake: Showing generic 'Success' or 'Error' messages
commonMistakes.why: Users need to know what succeeded or failed
commonMistakes.impact: Unclear feedback, user confusion
commonMistakes.fix: Be specific about what happened

commonMistakes.mistake: Not sanitizing user-generated content
commonMistakes.why: User input can contain malicious HTML/scripts
commonMistakes.impact: XSS vulnerability
commonMistakes.fix: Use preventXss=true when displaying user content

valueFormat.notes: Message text displayed in the toast. Keep concise (1-2 sentences max). Can include HTML if preventXss is properly configured. Use action-oriented language.
valueFormat.example: 'Campaign saved successfully' 'Error: Unable to connect to server' '3 items added to cart' 'Warning: Changes not saved'

commonMistakes.mistake: Writing long, verbose toast messages
commonMistakes.why: Toasts auto-dismiss and users don't have time to read long text
commonMistakes.impact: Users miss important information, frustration
commonMistakes.fix: Keep to 1-2 short sentences, max 60-80 characters

valueFormat.notes: Toast variant determining color scheme and semantic meaning. Common values: 'light' (default, neutral), 'success' (green), 'error' (red), 'warning' (yellow/orange), 'info' (blue). Affects background color and default icon.
valueFormat.example:
'success' // Green, checkmark icon
'error' // Red, error icon
'warning' // Orange, warning icon
'info' // Blue, info icon
'light' // Neutral (default)

valueFormat.notes: Controls toast visibility. Set to true to show toast, false to hide. Use v-model:status for reactive control. Toast typically auto-dismisses after timeout.
valueFormat.example:
true // Show toast
false // Hide toast

valueFormat.notes: Custom icon name from Insider icon system. Overrides default type-based icon. Leave empty to use default icon based on type (success=checkmark, error=alert, etc.).
valueFormat.example:
'' // Use default type icon
'check-circle' // Custom success icon
'alert-triangle' // Custom warning icon
'info-circle' // Custom info icon

valueFormat.notes: When true (default), shows icon alongside text. Set false for text-only toasts without icon. Icons help users quickly identify toast type (success, error, etc.).
valueFormat.example:
true // Show icon (default)
false // Text-only toast

valueFormat.structure: Array<{ text: string; variant?: string; onClick: Function; }>
valueFormat.notes: Array of action buttons shown in toast. Each button has text (label), optional variant (button style), and onClick handler. Use for actionable toasts like 'Undo', 'Retry', 'View Details'.

commonMistakes.mistake: Adding too many action buttons (3+)
commonMistakes.why: Toasts have limited space and auto-dismiss
commonMistakes.impact: Cluttered UI, users can't click all buttons before toast dismisses
commonMistakes.fix: Limit to 1-2 action buttons maximum

valueFormat.notes: When true, sanitizes HTML in text prop to prevent XSS attacks. MUST be true if text contains any user-generated content or HTML from untrusted sources.
valueFormat.example:
true // Sanitize HTML
false // No sanitization (default)

commonMistakes.mistake: Showing user input in toast without preventXss=true
commonMistakes.why: User input can contain malicious HTML/scripts
commonMistakes.impact: XSS vulnerability - serious security risk
commonMistakes.fix: Always use preventXss=true when text includes user-generated content

valueFormat.notes: When true, removes left margin/padding. Use when positioning toast in custom containers where default spacing isn't needed.
valueFormat.example:
true // Remove left margin
false // Default spacing (default)

helperFunctions.name: useToastManager
helperFunctions.description: Composable for global toast management with queue and auto-dismiss
helperFunctions.returnType: { toasts: Ref<Array>, show: Function, remove: Function, success: Function, error: Function, warning: Function, info: Function }

helperFunctions.name: createUndoToast
helperFunctions.description: Helper for creating undo-able action toasts

parameters.name: config
parameters.type: { message: string; onUndo: Function; onCommit: Function; undoText?: string; duration?: number; }

bestPractices.title: Keep Messages Concise
bestPractices.description: Toast messages should be 1-2 short sentences, max 60-80 characters
bestPractices.reasoning: Toasts auto-dismiss after 3-5 seconds. Users don't have time to read long messages. Brief messages are clearer.

bestPractices.title: Use Appropriate Types for Context
bestPractices.description: Match toast type to action result - success for confirmations, error for failures
bestPractices.code:
// Good:
type="success" // for save, create, complete
type="error" // for failures, errors
type="warning" // for cautions, non-critical issues
type="info" // for FYI messages

// Bad:
type="light" // for everything
bestPractices.reasoning: Color coding helps users quickly understand message severity. Consistent type usage builds user expectations.

bestPractices.title: Limit Action Buttons to 1-2 Maximum
bestPractices.description: Too many buttons clutter toast and users can't click before auto-dismiss
bestPractices.reasoning: Limited space and auto-dismiss timing. Users can only reasonably interact with 1-2 buttons before toast disappears.

bestPractices.title: Adjust Duration Based on Importance
bestPractices.description: Critical errors stay longer, simple confirmations dismiss quickly
bestPractices.code:
// Quick dismissal (2-3s):
success toasts: 3000ms
info toasts: 3000ms

// Longer duration (5-7s):
error toasts: 5000ms
warning toasts: 5000ms
toasts with actions: 5000ms+
bestPractices.reasoning: Errors need time for users to read and act. Success confirmations can disappear quickly. Action buttons need time to click.

performanceNotes.description: Showing too many toasts simultaneously impacts performance
performanceNotes.recommendation: Limit active toasts to 3-5 maximum. Queue additional toasts and show as others dismiss.
performanceNotes.impact: Medium: Multiple animated toasts can slow older devices

performanceNotes.description: Toast auto-dismiss timers must be cleaned up
performanceNotes.recommendation: Clear timeouts in onBeforeUnmount. Store timeout IDs and clear when component unmounts or toast is manually dismissed.
performanceNotes.impact: Medium: Uncleaned timers cause memory leaks over time

accessibilityNotes.description: Toasts must announce to screen readers using aria-live
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Toast container should have role='alert' or aria-live='polite' (for non-critical) or aria-live='assertive' (for errors)

accessibilityNotes.description: Action buttons in toasts must be keyboard accessible
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Ensure action buttons can be reached via Tab key. Toast should pause auto-dismiss when focused.

accessibilityNotes.description: Toast text must have sufficient contrast against background
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Ensure 4.5:1 contrast ratio for text. Test all toast types (success, error, warning, info) for contrast.
accessibilityNotes.example: Use design system color tokens that meet WCAG AA standards

accessibilityNotes.description: Users need time to read and act on toasts
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Provide at least 5 seconds for toasts with action buttons. Allow users to pause/extend timeout on hover or focus.

basicToast.title: Basic Success Toast
basicToast.code:
<template>
  <InToasts
    v-model:status="showToast"
    text="Campaign saved successfully"
    type="success"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
const showToast = ref(false);

const saveCampaign = async () => {
  await api.save();
  showToast.value = true;
  
  // Auto-dismiss after 3 seconds
  setTimeout(() => {
    showToast.value = false;
  }, 3000);
};
</script>

toastWithAction.title: Toast with Action Buttons
toastWithAction.code:
<template>
  <InToasts
    v-model:status="showToast"
    :text="toastMessage"
    type="success"
    :actionButtonsConfig="[
      { text: 'Undo', variant: 'secondary', onClick: handleUndo }
    ]"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
const showToast = ref(false);
const toastMessage = ref('');
let deletedItem = null;

const deleteItem = (item) => {
  deletedItem = item;
  // Perform delete
  api.delete(item.id);
  
  toastMessage.value = `${item.name} deleted`;
  showToast.value = true;
  
  setTimeout(() => {
    showToast.value = false;
    deletedItem = null;
  }, 5000);
};

const handleUndo = () => {
  if (deletedItem) {
    api.restore(deletedItem.id);
    showToast.value = false;
  }
};
</script>

errorToastWithRetry.title: Error Toast with Retry
errorToastWithRetry.code:
<template>
  <InToasts
    v-model:status="showErrorToast"
    text="Failed to save campaign"
    type="error"
    :actionButtonsConfig="[
      { text: 'Retry', variant: 'primary', onClick: retrySave }
    ]"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
const showErrorToast = ref(false);

const saveCampaign = async () => {
  try {
    await api.save();
  } catch (error) {
    showErrorToast.value = true;
  }
};

const retrySave = () => {
  showErrorToast.value = false;
  saveCampaign();
};
</script>

styling.notes: Toast colors are semantic - green for success, red for error, orange for warning, blue for info. Default 'light' type is neutral gray.

implementationPatterns.name: Global Toast Service
implementationPatterns.description: Centralized toast management using composable or global state
implementationPatterns.when: Need to show toasts from anywhere in the app without passing props through component tree. Common in large applications.

implementationPatterns.name: Toast with Undo Pattern
implementationPatterns.description: Allow users to undo destructive actions before they're committed
implementationPatterns.when: Destructive actions like delete, archive, bulk operations. Gives users safety net to reverse mistakes.

implementationPatterns.name: Stacked Toast Queue
implementationPatterns.description: Show multiple toasts simultaneously in a stack
implementationPatterns.when: Multiple operations happening simultaneously (batch processing, websocket notifications). Users need to see all updates.
cons: Can overwhelm screen with many toasts

useCases.title: CRUD Operation Feedback
useCases.description: Confirm create, update, delete operations
useCases.example: User saves a campaign: show 'Campaign saved successfully' (success). User deletes item: show 'Item deleted' with Undo button (success + action).

useCases.title: Form Validation Results
useCases.description: Notify users of validation errors or successful submission
useCases.example: Form submit fails validation: show 'Please fix 3 errors' (error). Form saves successfully: show 'Form submitted' (success).

useCases.title: Background Task Completion
useCases.description: Notify when async operations complete (exports, imports, processing)
useCases.example: Data export starts: show 'Exporting...' (info). Export completes: show 'Export ready' with Download button (success + action). Export fails: show 'Export failed' with Retry button (error + action).

useCases.title: Real-Time Notifications
useCases.description: Display incoming notifications from websockets or polling
useCases.example: New message received: show 'New message from John' with View button (info + action). System maintenance scheduled: show 'Scheduled maintenance in 10 minutes' (warning).

InTooltipV2.name: InTooltipV2
InTooltipV2.title: In Tooltip
InTooltipV2.typeDefs: import { DefineComponent } from 'vue'; /** * Static position options for tooltip placement. */ export type TooltipStaticPosition = | 'top center' | 'top left' | 'top right' | 'bottom center' | 'bottom left' | 'bottom right' | 'right center' | 'right top' | 'right bottom' | 'left center' | 'left top' | 'left bottom'; /** * Triangle position for the tooltip pointer. */ export type TrianglePosition = 'top' | 'bottom'; /** * Triangle alignment relative to tooltip edge. */ export type TriangleAlignment = 'start' | 'center' | 'end'; /** * Tooltip alignment options. */ export type TooltipAlignment = 'start' | 'center' | 'end' | false; /** * Position offset configuration. */ export interface PositionOffset { /** * Horizontal offset in pixels. */ x: number; /** * Vertical offset in pixels. */ y: number; } /** * Absolute position configuration. */ export interface AbsolutePosition { /** * Top position in pixels or CSS value. */ top?: string | number; /** * Right position in pixels or CSS value. */ right?: string | number; /** * Bottom position in pixels or CSS value. */ bottom?: string | number; /** * Left position in pixels or CSS value. */ left?: string | number; } /** * InTooltipV2 component props. */ export interface InTooltipV2Props { /** * Unique identifier for the tooltip element. * Required for proper tooltip positioning and lifecycle management. * * @required * @example id="help-tooltip" * @example id="field-description-tooltip" */ id: string; /** * Tooltip content text. * Supports HTML content when preventXss is false. * * @required * @example text="This is helpful information" * @example text="Important: Read this carefully" */ text: string; /** * Enables smart dynamic positioning based on viewport. * Automatically adjusts tooltip position to stay visible. * * @default true * @example :dynamic-position="true" */ dynamicPosition?: boolean; /** * Fixed position when dynamicPosition is false. * Determines where tooltip appears relative to trigger. * * @default 'top center' * @example static-position="bottom left" * @example static-position="right center" */ staticPosition?: TooltipStaticPosition; /** * Shows default tooltip icon as trigger element. * When false, use triggerElement slot for custom trigger. * * @default false * @example :icon-status="true" */ iconStatus?: boolean; /** * Position offset from trigger element in pixels. * * @default { x: 4, y: 4 } * @example :offset="{ x: 10, y: 15 }" */ offset?: PositionOffset; /** * Sanitizes HTML content to prevent XSS attacks. * Enable for user-generated content. * * @default false * @example :prevent-xss="true" */ preventXss?: boolean; /** * Maximum height of tooltip content in pixels. * Content becomes scrollable if exceeded. * * @default 320 * @example :max-height="200" */ maxHeight?: number; /** * Controls tooltip visibility. * Use to programmatically show/hide tooltip. * * @default true * @example :status="showTooltip" */ status?: boolean; /** * Forces tooltip alignment when dynamic positioning. * Overrides automatic alignment calculation. * * @default false * @example tooltip-alignment="center" * @example tooltip-alignment="start" */ tooltipAlignment?: TooltipAlignment; /** * Enables absolute CSS positioning mode. * Use with absolutePosition prop for manual positioning. * * @default false * @example :absolute-position-status="true" */ absolutePositionStatus?: boolean; /** * CSS position values when absolutePositionStatus is true. * Allows complete manual control over tooltip placement. * * @default {} * @example :absolute-position="{ top: '20px', left: '100px' }" */ absolutePosition?: AbsolutePosition; /** * Triangle alignment when using absolute positioning. * * @default 'center' * @example absolute-triangle-alignment="start" */ absoluteTriangleAlignment?: TriangleAlignment; /** * Triangle position when using absolute positioning. * * @default 'top' * @example absolute-triangle-position="bottom" */ absoluteTrianglePosition?: TrianglePosition; } /** * InTooltipV2 Component * * Advanced tooltip component with smart dynamic positioning, customizable * trigger elements, XSS protection, and flexible content slots. * * @example * // Basic tooltip with icon * * * @example * // With custom trigger element * * * * * @example * // With rich HTML content slot * * * * * * @example * // Static positioning * * * @example * // With XSS protection for user content * * * @example * // Conditional tooltip * * * */ declare const InTooltipV2: DefineComponent; export default InTooltipV2;

commonMistakes.title: Using absolutePosition with dynamicPosition enabled
commonMistakes.description: When dynamicPosition is true, absolutePosition prop is completely ignored
commonMistakes.impact: Tooltip doesn't appear where expected, absolutePosition settings have no effect

commonMistakes.title: Using string values for offset coordinates
commonMistakes.description: offset.x and offset.y must be numbers, not strings with units
commonMistakes.impact: Tooltip positioning breaks, may not appear or appear in wrong location

commonMistakes.title: Not considering viewport boundaries
commonMistakes.description: When using static or absolute positioning, tooltip may overflow viewport
commonMistakes.impact: Tooltip may be cut off or hidden when near viewport edges

commonMistakes.title: Not providing accessible content
commonMistakes.description: Tooltip content should be descriptive and accessible
commonMistakes.impact: Poor accessibility for screen readers, unclear purpose

commonMistakes.title: Using dynamic positioning for static layouts
commonMistakes.description: If tooltip target never moves, dynamic positioning is unnecessary overhead
commonMistakes.impact: Unnecessary calculations on every render, minor performance impact

valueFormat.structure: Offset object with x and y coordinates
valueFormat.notes: Controls the offset distance from the target element. Positive values move tooltip away from target, negative values move closer.

examples.code: :offset="{ x: 4, y: 4 }"
:offset="{ x: 0, y: 0 }"

commonMistakes.mistake: Using string values instead of numbers
commonMistakes.impact: Tooltip positioning breaks
commonMistakes.fix: Use numbers: { x: 4, y: 4 } not { x: '4px', y: '4px' }

commonMistakes.mistake: Setting very large offset values (>50)
commonMistakes.impact: Tooltip appears too far from target, poor UX
commonMistakes.fix: Keep offset values small (4-16px) for better UX

valueFormat.structure: Absolute positioning object with top, left, bottom, right coordinates
valueFormat.objectShape: { top?: number, left?: number, bottom?: number, right?: number }
valueFormat.notes: When provided, tooltip uses absolute positioning instead of dynamic positioning. Useful for fixed tooltip locations.

examples.code: :absolute-position="{ top: 0, left: 0 }"
:absolute-position="{ bottom: 0, right: 0 }"
:absolute-position="{ top: 20, left: '50%' }"

valueFormat.typescript: { top?: number; left?: number; bottom?: number; right?: number }

commonMistakes.mistake: Using absolutePosition with dynamicPosition=true
commonMistakes.impact: absolutePosition is ignored when dynamic positioning is enabled
commonMistakes.fix: Set dynamicPosition=false when using absolutePosition

commonMistakes.mistake: Not accounting for tooltip size
commonMistakes.impact: Tooltip may overflow viewport or cover target element
commonMistakes.fix: Calculate position considering tooltip dimensions

commonMistakes.mistake: Setting conflicting positions (both top and bottom)
commonMistakes.impact: Unpredictable positioning behavior
commonMistakes.fix: Use either top OR bottom, and either left OR right

valueFormat.notes: When true, tooltip automatically positions itself to stay within viewport bounds. When false, uses staticPosition or absolutePosition.

commonMistakes.mistake: Setting dynamicPosition=true with absolutePosition
commonMistakes.impact: absolutePosition is ignored
commonMistakes.fix: Use dynamicPosition=false when you want absolute positioning

valueFormat.notes: Format: '[vertical] [horizontal]' where vertical is top/bottom/center and horizontal is left/right/center

examples.code: static-position="top center"
static-position="bottom right"
static-position="center left"

commonMistakes.mistake: Using invalid position keywords
commonMistakes.impact: Tooltip may not position correctly
commonMistakes.fix: Use only: top, bottom, center (vertical) and left, right, center (horizontal)

commonMistakes.mistake: Incorrect order (horizontal before vertical)
commonMistakes.impact: May cause unexpected positioning
commonMistakes.fix: Always use format: 'vertical horizontal' (e.g., 'top center' not 'center top')

helperFunctions.name: createTooltipConfig

helperFunctions.example: const config = createTooltipConfig('Save changes', 'bottom right');

helperFunctions.name: truncateWithTooltip
helperFunctions.description: Truncate text and determine if tooltip is needed

helperFunctions.example: const { displayText, tooltipText, needsTooltip } = truncateWithTooltip(longText, 50);

bestPractices.title: Use Dynamic Positioning for Responsive Layouts
bestPractices.description: Enable dynamic positioning when tooltip target may be near viewport edges or in scrollable containers
bestPractices.code:
<InTooltipV2
  :dynamic-position="true"
  tooltip-text="This tooltip will adjust its position to stay visible"
/>
bestPractices.benefit: Ensures tooltip is always visible and readable, better UX across different screen sizes

bestPractices.title: Keep Offset Values Small
bestPractices.description: Use small offset values (4-16px) to maintain visual connection between tooltip and target
bestPractices.code:
<InTooltipV2
  :offset="{ x: 8, y: 8 }"
  tooltip-text="Helpful information"
/>
bestPractices.benefit: Clear visual relationship between tooltip and its trigger element

bestPractices.title: Use Static Positioning for Fixed Layouts
bestPractices.description: When tooltip target has fixed position, use static positioning for better performance
bestPractices.code:
<InTooltipV2
  :dynamic-position="false"
  static-position="top center"
  :offset="{ x: 0, y: 8 }"
/>
bestPractices.benefit: Better performance, no unnecessary position calculations

bestPractices.title: Provide Clear, Concise Tooltip Text
bestPractices.description: Keep tooltip content brief and informative (1-2 sentences max)
bestPractices.code:
<InTooltipV2
  tooltip-text="Save your changes before leaving this page"
  :prevent-xss="true"
/>
bestPractices.benefit: Better readability, faster comprehension, improved accessibility

bestPractices.title: Enable XSS Protection for User-Generated Content
bestPractices.description: Always enable preventXss when displaying user-provided content in tooltips
bestPractices.code:
<InTooltipV2
  :tooltip-text="userProvidedText"
  :prevent-xss="true"
/>
bestPractices.benefit: Prevents XSS attacks, secure handling of untrusted content

performanceNotes.description: Dynamic positioning recalculates on every render to detect viewport boundaries.
performanceNotes.recommendation: Use static positioning (dynamic-position="false") when tooltip placement is predictable. Only use dynamic for edge cases near viewport boundaries.

performanceNotes.description: When prevent-xss is enabled, tooltip text is sanitized on every render.
performanceNotes.recommendation: Keep prevent-xss="true" (default) for security. If displaying trusted content only, can disable for slight performance gain.

performanceNotes.description: Many tooltips with dynamic positioning can impact scroll performance due to continuous recalculation.
performanceNotes.recommendation: Limit dynamic tooltips on scrollable pages. Use static positioning for table headers or repeated elements.

accessibilityNotes.description: Tooltip text should provide useful information, not just repeat visible text.
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Explain what an element does or provide context. Avoid redundancy.
accessibilityNotes.example:
Good: 'Delete this item permanently'
Bad: 'Delete' (when button already says Delete)

accessibilityNotes.description: Component automatically adds role='tooltip' and aria-describedby for screen readers.
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: No action needed - component handles ARIA internally.

accessibilityNotes.description: Tooltip background and text must meet WCAG AA contrast ratio (4.5:1).
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Default theme meets standards. If customizing colors, test contrast with tools like WebAIM.
accessibilityNotes.example: Default: Dark gray background (#333) with white text - 12.6:1 ratio

accessibilityNotes.description: Tooltips should be accessible via keyboard focus, not just hover.
accessibilityNotes.recommendation: Ensure parent element is focusable (button, link, or tabindex="0"). Tooltip shows on focus.

<!-- V1 Implementation -->
<template>
  <InButton
    id="submit-btn"
    type="primary"
    :disabled="isDisabled"
    :loading="isLoading"
    @click="handleClick"

    Submit
  </InButton>

<script>
import { InButton } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

export default {
  components: { InButton },
  data() {
    return {
      isDisabled: false,
      isLoading: false
    };
  },
  methods: {
    handleClick() {
      this.isLoading = true;
      // ... action
    }
  }
};
</script>

InDataTable-to-V2.description: Major migration from InDataTable (V1) to InDataTableV2. V2 is built on AG Grid with completely restructured column definitions, renamed props (status suffix pattern), and new event names. Requires significant refactoring.

tableFields.notes: Column structure changed to AG Grid format: label → headerName, renderer → cellRenderer

noDataDescription.transformCode:
// Add Text suffix
no-data-description-text="Try different filters"

actions.transformCode:
// Actions handled differently in V2
// Use custom cellRenderer in columnOptions
actions.notes: V2 uses AG Grid cellRenderer for actions column

paginationPath.transformCode: // Handle in fetchData event or API layer
paginationPath.notes: V2 expects standardized API response format

sortOrder.transformCode:
// Set sort in column definition
{ field: 'date', headerName: 'Date', sort: 'desc' }
sortOrder.notes: Default sort is set per-column in columnOptions

fixFirstColumn.transformCode:
// Set pinned in column definition
{ field: 'name', headerName: 'Name', pinned: 'left' }
fixFirstColumn.notes: V2 uses AG Grid pinned property per-column

fixLastColumn.transformCode:
// Set pinned in column definition
{ field: 'actions', headerName: '', pinned: 'right' }
fixLastColumn.notes: V2 uses AG Grid pinned property per-column

isWrapperBox.notes: V2 uses inContainerLayout with options object

httpFetch.notes: V2 uses fetchData event for custom fetch logic

httpOptions.transformCode:
// Limited to httpMethod in V2
http-method="POST"
httpOptions.notes: V2 only supports httpMethod, handle headers in API layer

detailRow.notes: V2 uses built-in nested table instead of custom component

rowClass.transformCode: // Use AG Grid getRowClass or cellClass in columns
rowClass.notes: Handle via AG Grid API or cellClass

formatMapping.transformCode:
// Use valueFormatter per column
{ field: 'date', valueFormatter: params => formatDate(params.value) }
formatMapping.notes: V2 uses AG Grid valueFormatter per column

@onLoad.payloadChange: Payload includes AG Grid API instead of total

@paginationCount.payloadChange: Use totalData prop or data-loaded event
